adjourned October 2, 1989.

uary 21, 1989; remarks by the Chief Justice.

moved admissions to Bar et seq.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1988
1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1987 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed
and the October 1988 Term is now convened. Today's orders of the
Court have been certified by the Chief Justice, filed with the Clerk, and
will not be announced orally. The Court now recognizes the Solicitor
General, Mr. Charles Fried."
Mr. Solicitor General Charles Fried said:
"Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I have the honor to
present to the Court the seventy-sixth Attorney General of the United.
States, the Honorable Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania."
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Attorney General, on behalf of the Court I welcome you as the
chief law officer of the government and as an officer of this Court. We
welcome you to the performance of the very important duties which will
rest on you by virtue of your office. Your commission as Attorney Gen-
eral of the United States will be placed in the records of the Court. We
wish you well in your new office.”
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-1337. Katherine A. Boersma, Personal Representative of the
Estate of Lloyd Boersma, and Phyllis Boersma, etc., Appellants .
Donna Karnes, Tax Commissioner of Nebraska, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Justice White and Justice Blackmun would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 87-1586. Bruno G. Chalko, Appellant. Sharon E. Chalko.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate Dis-
trict. The motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 87-1647. James G. Anderson, Jr., Appellant. Sno-King Village
Association, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wyoming.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1988
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-1783. William A. Brackenridge, Appellant v. Ametek, Inc.,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1837. Parkview Associates, Appellant v. City of New York,
et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

Lesnansky. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.

CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1898. Larry W. Bryant, Petitioner v. Frank C. Carlucci, Sec-
retary of Defense, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Webster v. Doe, 486 U.S. ——— (1988).
No. 87–1933. Sandy Golgart, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Central Plas-
tics Company. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Budinich v. Becton Dickinson and Company,
486 U.S. (1988) and Buchanan v. Stanships, Inc., 485 U.S.
(1988).
- -

MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1988
7
No. 87-2011. Washington State Electrical Contractors Association,
Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Frank Forrest, et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated.
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Patrick v. Burget, 486
U.S. (1988). Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
-
No. 87-2079. Frank B. Shirk, et ux., dba Oregon Meat Cutting
School, Petitioners v. Ann McLaughlin, Secretary of Labor. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
McLaughlin v. Richland Shoe Company, 486 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-6717. Bonnide W. Johnson, Petitioner v. Willie E. Johnson,
Warden, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certio-
rari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Houston v. Lack, 487 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-6751. Kurt Max Wilfried Miller, Jr., Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Houston v. Lack, 487 U.S. (1988).
-
No. 87-6833. Oscar Lloyd, Petitioner v. North Carolina. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of North Carolina for fur-
ther consideration in light of Mills v. Maryland, 486 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-6948. Mary Alice Wolf, Petitioner . United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of

8
MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1988
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Arizona v. Roberson, 486 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-7110. Brett C. Kimberlin, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Houston v. Lack, 487 U.S. — (1988).
No. 87-7290. Kerry Max Cook, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further consid-
eration in light of Satterwhite v. Texas, 486 U.S. — (1988).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. - Bank of San Marino Building, Ltd., Petitioner . Default
Service Company, et al. The motion of one who is not a member of the
Bar of this Court to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certio-
rari is denied.
No. . William J. Drabick, III, Petitioner v. David Drabick. The
motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of
indigency executed by petitioner is granted.
No. Alvin Bernard Ford, etc., Petitioner v. Richard L. Dugger,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency executed
by petitioner is granted.
-
No. Jesse Avila Valles, Petitioner 1. James Lynaugh, Director,
Texas Department of Corrections. The motion to direct the Clerk to file
a petition for writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. D-717. In the Matter of Richard Joseph Alfieri. Richard Joseph
Alfieri, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on June 20, 1988, is
hereby discharged.

No. 87-7077. Charles J. McDevitt, Sr., Petitioner 1. City of Philadel-
phia, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 24, 1988, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983),
we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

No. 88-5054. James W. Sullivan, Appellant 2. Katherine J. Sullivan.
The motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Appellant is allowed until October 24, 1988, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a statement
as to jurisdiction in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co..
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would dismiss the appeal for want of
jurisdiction and, treating the papers whereon the appeal would be
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, deny the petition for a writ
of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.

consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1988
93
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-76. Crocker National Bank, et al., Appellants 2. City and
County of San Francisco. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. The
Chief Justice would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 88-179. Jonathan Club, Appellant . California Coastal Commis-
sion. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 88-253. Denzil Pritchard, et ux., Appellants v. Board of Commis-
sioners of Calvert County, Maryland, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 88-298. Market Street Mission, Appellant v. Bureau of Rooming
and Boarding House Standards, New Jersey Department of Commu-
nity Affairs. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 88-219. Mannheim Books, Inc., Appellant 2. County of Cook,
Illinois. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set the case
for oral argument.
No. 88-258. Helmut Rampp and Layton Sorber, Appellants u. Gil-
bert Gleco, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-377. Robert A. Fraychineaud, Jr., Appellant . City of New
Orleans. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.

94
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1988
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 88-405. Arthur Ditmar, Appellant v. Needham, Harper, World-
wide, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-295. Local Union 598, Plumbers & Pipefitters Industry Jour-
neymen & Apprentices Training Fund, Appellant 2. J. A. Jones Con-
struction Company, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of Foundation for Fair Con-
tracting for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The judg-
ment is affirmed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1929. Mark Lynn Fortney, et al., Petitioners v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Berkovitz v. United States, 486 U.S. – (1988).
Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom the Chief Justice, Jus-
tice O'Connor and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 88-5215. Charles A. Foster, Petitioner . Oklahoma. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for
further consideration in light of Maynard v. Cartwright, 486 U.S.
(1988).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-176. John T. Fort. Applicant 2. National American Insurance
Company, et al. The application for stay and other relief addressed to
Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-242. Metromedia, Inc., et al., Applicants 1. April Enterprises.
Inc. The application for stay presented to Justice O'Connor and by her
referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that the judgment of
the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, case

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1988
95
No. B022890, entered June 9, 1988, is stayed pending the timely filing
and disposition of a petition for writ of certiorari. In the event the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is denied, this order terminates automati-
cally. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be granted, this order
is to remain in effect pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.
This order is further conditioned upon the bond presently in force
remaining in effect. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this order.

is ordered that Robert N. Bussey, of St. Petersburg, Florida, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Marvin A. Newman, of Monticello, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue.
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 88-155. Texas, Petitioner v. Gregory Lee Johnson. The applica-

order is to remain in effect pending the issuance of the mandate of this
Court.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1988
123
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-289. Walter Bell, Jr., Applicant v. James A. Lynaugh, Direc-
tor, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of sentence of death, presented to Justice White and by him
referred to the Court, is granted pending the timely filing and dis-
position by this Court of a petition for a writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted,
this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of
this Court.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1988
125
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-139. James A. Rhodes, et al., Petitioners v. Larry Stewart.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
Justice Brennan joins.
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-1034. Virginia, Appellant v. American Booksellers Associa-
tion, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Commonwealth of Virginia v. American Book-
sellers Association, Inc., et al. — Va. — (Sept. 23. 1988)
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-710. In the Matter of Disbarment of Terrence J. Ford. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-715. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles A. Youts. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-737. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerald Weatherly. It is
ordered that Gerald Weatherly, of Dallas, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-738. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerome Joseph Burke, Jr.
It is ordered that Jerome Joseph Burke, Jr., of West Hempstead, New
York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a

126
MONDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1988
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-739. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald R. Benjamin. The
motion of Ronald R. Benjamin to be suspended from the practice of law
in this Court for six months, nunc pro tunc, is denied.
It is ordered that Ronald R. Benjamin, of Binghamton, New York,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 87-201. Gerald E. Mansell, Appellant v. Gaye Mansell. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae,
out-of-time, is granted.
No. 87-1245. Texas Monthly, Inc., Appellant v. Bob Bullock, Comp-
troller of Public Accounts of the State of Texas, et al. The motion of
appellant for leave to file a reply brief, out-of-time, is denied.
No. 87-1383. United States, Appellant . Irwin Halper. John G.
Roberts, Jr., Esquire, of Alexandria, Virginia, a member of the Bar of
this Court, is invited to brief and argue this case, as amicus curiae, in
support of the judgment below.
No. 87-1868. Mead Corporation, Petitioner v. B. E. Tilley, et al. The
motion of respondents to substitute Richard H. Wall, Executor of the
Estate of David H. Wall, in place of David H. Wall, deceased, is denied.
No. 87-5765. Kevin N. Stanford, Petitioner 1. Kentucky. The order
of October 11, 1988, granting the petition for a writ of certiorari is
amended as follows:
"The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted limited to
Question VIII presented by the petition. The case is set for oral
argument in tandem with No. 87-6026, Wilkins v. Missouri, in place of
No. 87-5666, High v. Zant."
No. 88-348. New Orleans Public Service, Inc., Petitioner u. Council
of City of New Orleans, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 88-389. Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio, Appel-
lant . June M. Betts. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of appellee for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1988
141
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico. It
is ordered that D. Monte Pascoe, Esquire, of Denver, Colorado, be
appointed Special Master in place of Charles J. Meyers, deceased.
The Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and conditions.
for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceed-
ings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and
take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it
necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit such
reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1988
143
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-317. William Armontrout, Warden, Applicant v. George Mer-
cer. The application for the Attorney General of Missouri for an order
to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit presented to
Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court is denied.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1988
145
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 88-5687. Leo E. Edwards, Jr., Petitioner v. Gene A. Scroggy,
Commissioner, Mississippi Department of Corrections, et al. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
White and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the dispo-
sition by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the
petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted,
this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of
this Court. Justice Scalia took no part in the consideration or decision.
of this application.

and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Dissenting statement by

MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1988
149
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-161. Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Thomas A. Bruder, Jr. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Pennsylvania,
Philadelphia Office. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Superior Court of of
Pennsylvania for further proceeding not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Marshall
joins.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-2058. Cornhusker Christian Childrens Home, Inc., Appellant
v. Department of Social Services of Nebraska, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 88-177. VECO International, Inc., et al., Appellants . Alaska
Public Offices Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alaska.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 88-228. Jeffrey St. Hilaire, Appellant 2. Maine. Appeal from the
Supreme Judicial Court of Maine. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 88-320. Thomas Robert Kammer, Appellant 1. Christine J.
Young. Appeal from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 88-413. Raymond L. Bovino, Appellant 2. Middlesex County
Board of Social Services. Appeal from the Superior Court of New
Jersey, Appellate Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-

150
MONDAY, OCTOBER 31. 1988
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5439. Matthew S. Ikeni. Appellant 2. California Superior
Court of Fresno County and State Farm Fire and Casualty Insurance
Company. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appel-
late District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5464. Lowell Buller, et al, Appellants 1. Hurley State Bank.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Dakota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-381. John Geever, et ux., Appellants . Illinois. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1467. Exxon Company, U.S.A., Petitioner . Banque de
Paris et des Pays-Bas. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The judgment is vacated and case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Kerr Construction Co. v. Plains
National Bank, No. 07-86-0205-CV. (Tex. App. Amarillo 1987,
writ denied).
No. 88-28. Cyril Onwuasoanya, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
with instructions to dismiss the proceedings arising out of petitioner's
Rule 41(e) motion as moot. United States v. Muningswear, 340 U.S. 36,
38-39 (1950).
No. 88-41. Board of Governors of State Colleges and Universities,
et al., Petitioners 1. Robin Akins, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The pe-
tition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit for further consideration in light of Torres v. Oakland Scaven-
ger Company, 487 U.S. — (1988).

MONDAY, OCTOBER 31. 1988
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
151
No. A-253. Vincent Victor Roggio, Applicant v. United States. The
application for release pending appeal addressed to Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff 2. State of New Mexico.
The motion for allowance of fees and disbursements on behalf of the late
Charles J. Meyers, Special Master, is granted and the allocation for
total services and disbursements set forth in the motion is approved.
This amount is to be paid equally by the parties. Justice Stevens took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 112, Original. State of Wyoming, Plaintiff r. State of Oklahoma.
The motion of defendant to dismiss the complaint is denied. Defendant
is allowed 30 days within which to file an answer.
No. 87-201. Gerald E. Mansell, Appellant v. Gaye Mansell. The mo-
tion of Women's Equity Action League, et al., for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted.
No. 87-1855. Thomas K. Gilhool, Secretary of Education of Penn-
sylvania, Petitioner v. Russell A. Muth, Jr., et al. The motion of re-
spondent Russell A. Muth for leave to proceed further herein in forma
pauperis is granted.
No. 87-1939. Geoffrey W. Barnard, etc., Petitioner v. Susan Esposi-
to Thorstenn, et al.; and
No. 87-2008. Virgin Islands Bar Association, Petitioner v. Susan
Esposito Thorstenn, et al. The motion of Paul Hoffman, et al., for leave
to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 87-2066. W. S. Kirkpatrick & Co., Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Environmental Tectonics Corporation. International. The Solicitor
General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 88-399. Billie Hammond, Petitioner 1. Terminal Railroad Associ-
ation of St. Louis. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 88-317. Jack R. Duckworth, Petitioner 1. Gary James Eagan.
The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Howard B. Eisenberg. Esquire, of Carbondale, Illinois, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 88-5412. Agnes L. Foy, et vir, Petitioners 1. Northeast Subur-
ban Life. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma

152
MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1988
pauperis is denied. Petitioners are allowed until November 21, 1988,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.
No. 88-5416. Jacques D. Christian, Petitioner v. Otis R. Bowen, Sec-
retary of Health and Human Services. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until
November 21, 1988, within which to pay the docketing fee required by
Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice
Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald
Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.
No. 88-5480. Oscar E. Weigang, Jr., Appellant, v. Pearl River
County Board of Supervisors, et al. The motion of appellant for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Appellant is allowed until Novem-
ber 21, 1988, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule
45(a) and to submit a statement as to jurisdiction in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall
and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would dismiss the appeal
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 87-2127. American Foreign Service Association, et al., Appel-
lants. Steven Garfinkel, Director, Information Security Oversight.
Office, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of Columbia. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1988
179
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 87-1961. Town of Huntington, New York, et al., Appellants 2.
Huntington Branch, National Association for the Advancement of Col-
ored People, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. The motion of New York Planning Federation for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion per curiam. Justice White, Justice Marshall, and Justice
Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-461. Kimber Petroleum Corporation, Appellant v. Christo-
pher J. Daggett, Acting Commissioner, New Jersey Department of
Environmental Protection. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New
Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 88-477. Joe Monastero, Sam Katzman, and Marlene "Mardy"
McCullough, Appellants 1. Nebraska. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 88-478. Stanley Sterner and Rick S. Sterner. Appellants
Carol J. Jones, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1988

No. D-740. In the Matter of Disbarment of Russell B. Smith, III. It
is ordered that Russell B. Smith, III, of Houston, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1988
181
ville, Virginia, is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in
this case.
No. 88-5054. James W. Sullivan, Appellant 2. Katherine J. Sullivan.
The motion of appellant for reconsideration of order denying leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 88-5526. Rolf Betka, Appellant v. A-T Industries, Inc., etc.,
et al. The motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Appellant is allowed until November 28, 1988, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a statement
as to jurisdiction in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald
Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would dismiss the appeal without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-5563. Paul D. Johnson, Jr., Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until November 28, 1988, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the mo-
tion to proceed in forma pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 87-6997. Eugene John Carella, Appellant 1. California. Appeal
from the Appellate Department, Superior Court of California, Los
Angeles County. The motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 87-1168. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Don-
ald E. Clark, et ux. Argued by Mr. Alan I. Horowitz for the petitioner
and by Mr. Walter B. Slocombe for the respondents.
No. 87-1160. Duquesne Light Company and Pennsylvania Power
Company, Appellants v. David M. Barasch, etc., et al. Argued by Mr.
Peter Buscemi for the appellants and by Mr. Irwin A. Popowsky for the
appellees.
No. 87-548. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Independent
Federation of Flight Attendants. Argued by Mr. Murray Gartner for
the petitioner, by Mr. Lawrence S. Robbins for the National Labor
Relations Board, as amicus curiae, in support of the petitioner by spe-
cial leave of Court, and by Mr. John P. Hurley for the respondent.
No. 86-1940. Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, et al.,
Petitioners v. Edward Lynn. Argued by Mr. Donald W. Fisher for the
petitioners and by Mr. Bruce M. Stark for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-363. Jeffery J. Daugherty, Applicant 1. Florida, et al.; and
No. A-366. Jeffery J. Daugherty, Applicant 2. Richard L. Dugger,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The applications for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy and
by him referred to the Court are denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins and with whom Justice
Blackmun joins as to Part II. Justice Stevens would grant the applica-
tions for stay.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1988
197
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and Justice
Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 86-1593. Shell Oil Company, Appellant . Department of Reve-
nue, State of Florida. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of
Florida for further consideration in light of Shell Oil Company v. Iowa
Department of Revenue, 488 U.S. (1988).
-
No. 88-534. Jim Shoulders, et al., Appellants . McCracken County,
Kentucky, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kentucky. The mo-
tion of appellees for award of costs is denied. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 88-560. Theresa F. Mitan, Appellant v. Frank J. Mitan. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

the District Court of Texas, 227th Judicial District, Bexar County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.

ordered that Samuel Weinberg, of Roslyn Harbor, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 88-5403. Clarence R. Hayes, Petitioner 2. Western Weighing
and Inspection Bureau. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until December 5, 1988,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.

OPINION
No. 87-1277. A. L. Lockhart, Director, Arkansas Department of
Correction, Petitioner v. Johnny Lee Nelson. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the
Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.
Adjourned until Monday, November 28, 1988 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1988
217
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-400. William Armontrout, Warden, Applicant v. Gerald
Smith, etc. The application of the Attorney General of Missouri for an
order to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of death entered by
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit presented to
Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court is denied.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1988
219
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-537. Patrick W. Price, Appellant 2. City of San Marcos,
Texas, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Third District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 88-571. James Harold Cossett, et ux., Appellants 2. Merchants
and Mechanics Federal Savings & Loan Association, et al. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-575. William R. Burt. Appellant . Maui Architectural
Group, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 88-609. Earlene Polyak, Appellant 2. Buford Evans & Sons. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 88-5589. Thomas Priovolos, Appellant 2. Heart of Cedar Lane.
Inc., et al. Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jersey. Appellate
Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5660. Laurette Tedders, Appellant, r. Ronald Lord, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.

220
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1988
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 88-5228. Scott Chisholm, Appellant 1. Kansas. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Kansas. The motion of appellant for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Kansas for further consideration in
light of Coy v. Iowa, 487 U.S. (1988).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . BMT Commodity Corp. and Delca Distributors, Inc., Peti-
tioners. United States. The motion for leave to file a supplement to
the petition for writ of certiorari under seal is granted.
--
No. Beth A. Friedman, Petitioner u. Larry E. Katz, et al. The
motion for leave to file portions of the appendix to the petition for writ
of certiorari under seal is denied.
No. —. Eric Laupot, Petitioner v. Alexander Berley, et al. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari is denied.
No. D-724. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brick P. Storts, III. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-729. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter T. Bongiorno. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-742. In the Matter of Disbarment of Helen Rice Frederick. It
is ordered that Helen Rice Frederick, of Carson, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring her to show cause why she should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-743. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph R. Carter, Jr. It
is ordered that Joseph R. Carter, Jr., of Los Angeles, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-744. In the Matter of Disbarment of Samuel J. Hecht. It is
ordered that Samuel J. Hecht, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-745. In the Matter of Disbarment of Barry Howard Denker. It
is ordered that Barry Howard Denker, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1988
221
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-746. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Leroy Lindquist. It
is ordered that John Leroy Lindquist, of Coral Springs, Florida, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 87-6997. Eugene John Carella, Appellant v. California. The
order entered November 7, 1988, is amended to read as follows: "The
motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
In this case probable jurisdiction is noted limited to Questions I, II, III,
IV, V, and VII presented by the jurisdictional statement."
No. 87-5840. Edward McNamara, Appellant . County of San Diego
Department of Social Services. The motion of Christian R. Van Deusen
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided
argument and for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 88-90. Chabad, Petitioner v. American Civil Liberties Union, et
al. The application for recall and stay of the mandate of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit presented to Justice
Brennan and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun
would grant the application.
No. 88-5188. Bernice Bennett, Petitioner 2. Corroon & Black Corp.,
et al. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of the order of Court
denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 88-5580. Cameron Wehringer, Appellant v. New Hampshire.
The motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Appellant is allowed until December 19, 1988, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a statement as
to jurisdiction in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would dismiss the appeal without reaching
the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-5828. Horace Franklin Dunkins, Jr., Petitioner 1. Morris L.
Thigpen, Commissioner, Alabama Department of Corrections, et al.
The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to
the Court is denied.

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-1589. Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al.; and
No. 87-1888. Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al. Petitions for writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
are granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour and
thirty minutes is allotted for oral argument.

and Justice Marshall join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1988
249
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-539. James E. Poole, Jr., et al., Appellants . Emma
Gresham, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Georgia. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Georgia to consider the question of mootness. Justice Brennan, Jus-
tice White, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun would affirm the
judgment.
No. 88-665. Jerry H. Summers, Appellant v. Robert L. Thompson,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Eastern Division.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 88-5671. Roscoe W. Fields, Sr., Appellant v. Kyle Testerman, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 88-5672. Roscoe W. Fields, Sr., Appellant v. Martin Marietta,
Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5673. Roscoe W. Fields, Sr., Appellant 1. Roy Pruett, etc., et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
--
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Gerald Smith, Petitioner 1. Mississippi. The motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency ex-
ecuted by the petitioner is granted. The motion of Missouri Public De-

250
MONDAY, DECEMBER 5. 1988
fender Commission, et al. to be substituted as next friends for Gerald
Smith is denied.
No. A-419. Yonkers Racing Corporation, Applicant v. City of Yon-
kers, et al. The application for recall, stay and other relief addressed to
the Chief Justice and referred to the Court is denied. The Chief Justice
and Justice Kennedy would grant the application.
No. D-747. In the Matter of Disbarment of Nicholas W. Williams. It
is ordered that Nicholas W. Williams, of Berea, Kentucky, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
The motion of the Special Master for award of interim fees and ex-
penses is granted and the allocation set forth in the motion is approved.
This amount is to be paid equally by the parties.
No. 87-826. Jerome F. Goldberg and Robert McTigue, Appellants v.
Roger D. Sweet, Director, Illinois Department of Revenue, et al.; and
No. 87-1101. GTE Sprint Communications Corporation, Appellant v.
Roger D. Sweet, Director, Illinois Department of Revenue, et al. The
motion of appellants Goldberg and McTigue for leave to file a supple-
mental brief after argument is granted.
No. 87-1661. ASARCO Incorporated, et al., Petitioners u. Frank
Kadish, et ux., et al. The motion of Alaska Miners Association, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 87-1848. City of Dallas, et al., Petitioners v. Charles M.
Stanglin, Individually, and dba Twilight Skating Rink. The motion of
U.S. Conference of Mayors, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted.
No. 88-266. Oklahoma Tax Commission, Petitioner 2. Jan Graham,
et al. The motion of Stanley J. Alexander, Esquire, to permit David
Allen Miley, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 88-603. Arizona, Petitioner 1. Conrad Marion Flint. The Solici-
tor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of
the United States.

for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 88-5686. In Re Sylvester Jones. The petition for writ of manda-
mus is denied.

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1988
265
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-821. Pittston Coal Group, et al., Petitioners v. James Sebben,
et al.; and
No. 87-827. Ann McLaughlin, Secretary of Labor, et al., Petitioners
v. James Sebben, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit; and
No. 87–1095. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, Petitioner 2. Charlie Broyles, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The judgment of the Fourth Circuit is affirmed and the
judgment of the Eighth Circuit is reversed and Nos. 87-821 and 87-827
are remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit with instructions to direct the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Iowa to dismiss the petition for mandamus. Opin-
ion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 87-751. Frank C. Carlucci, Secretary of Defense, et al., Petition-
ers v. John Doe. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.
No. 87-5840. Edward McNamara, Appellant v. County of San Diego
Department of Social Services. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a properly presented federal question. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by the Chief Justice.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1988
269
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and
Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-5223. James Olden, Petitioner v. Kentucky. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Marshall. Justice Brennan took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-554. Bill Clinton, Governor of Arkansas, et al., Appellants v.
Elbert Smith, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Arkansas. The judgment is affirmed. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 88-671. Richard A. Sprague, Appellant . Greg Walter, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented federal question.
Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 88-5761. Cameron Wehringer, Appellant, . Departmental Dis-
ciplinary Committee for the First Judicial Department. Appeal from
the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial
Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1720. Hubert C. Taylor, Petitioner 1. Peabody Coal Com-
pany, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court

270
MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1988
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Pittston Coal Group v. Sebben, 488 U.S.
(1988). Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1988
271
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
It is ordered that Thomas H. Jackson, Esquire, of Charlottesville, Vir-
ginia, be appointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix the
time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct
subsequent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses,
issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such
as he may deem it necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed
to submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct. Justice
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 114, Original. State of Louisiana, Plaintiff . State of Missis-
sippi, et al. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is denied.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Stevens and
Justice Scalia join. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.

Appellants v. San Francisco County Democratic Central Committee, et
al. The motion of Libertarian National Committe for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. The Chief Justice and Justice Brennan
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

Kadish, et ux., et al. The motion of Clinton Campbell Contractor, Inc.
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Brennan and
Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.

rence Williams, Sr. The motion of respondent to dismiss the writ of cer-

MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1988
County of Allegheny, et al. for divided argument is denied. The motion

No. 88-5808. Nyahuma Kamau Macharia, Petitioner . Donald P.
Hodel, Secretary of the Interior. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until January
3, 1989, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a)
and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Marshall; Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.

OPINIONS
No. 87-1097. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner 1. Georgetown University Hospital, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 87–1061. National Collegiate Athletic Association, Petitioner .
Jerry Tarkanian. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nevada.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Stevens announced by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and
Justice O'Connor join.

284
MONDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1988
No. 87-981. Beech Aircraft Corporation, Petitioner . John C.
Rainey, etc., et al.; and
No. 87-1028. Beech Aerospace Services, Inc., Petitioner v. John C.
Rainey, etc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed
in part and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Brennan announced by the Chief Justice. Opinion by the Chief Justice.
dissenting in part with whom Justice O'Connor joins.
No. 87-271. Harbison-Walker Refractories, A Division of Dresser In-
dustries, Inc., Petitioner 2. Eugene F. Brieck. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The writ of
certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam
announced by The Chief Justice. Justice White dissents.

Adjourned until Monday, January 9, 1989 at 10 o'clock.
No. 88-6092. Raymond Landry, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death, presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court, is denied. Dissenting statement by
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 88-6104. Samuel C. Hawkins, Petitioner v. Lynaugh, Director,
Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of execution.
of sentence of death presented to Justice White and by him referred to
the Court is granted pending the disposition by this Court of the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be
denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event the petition for
writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pending the send-
ing down of the judgment of this Court. The Chief Justice and Justice
White would deny the application for stay.

tice Marshall.

MONDAY, JANUARY 9, 1989
289
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-734. Cyril E. Sagan, Appellant 2. Pennsylvania Public Televi-
sion Network, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 88-5837. Paul Ezra Rhoades, Appellant 2. Idaho. Appeal from
the Dist. Ct., 7th Judicial District Bonneville County. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 88-759. Bret S. Clark, Appellant v. Florida Bar. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition.
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-804. Tony Lynn Davis, Appellant . Oklahoma. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-852. Robert E. Hooker, et ux., Appellants 1. United States.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 88-896. Earlene Polyak, Appellant . Frank Hulen and Wilma
Lesnansky. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5425. Gerald K. Lyerla. Appellant 1. South Dakota. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of South Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

290
MONDAY, JANUARY 9, 1989
No. 88-5852. Rolf Betka, Appellant v. City of West Linn, etc., et al.;
and Rolf Betka, Appellant v. City of West Linn, etc., et al. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5785. Paul O'Leary, Appellant, 2. Steven E. Yarmosky.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Massachusetts. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1630. Reliance Insurance Company, Petitioner 2. Glados, Inc.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. The motion of respondent to award attorney's
fees is denied. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Beech Aircraft Corporation v. Rainey, 488 U.S. — (1988).
ORDERS IN Pending Cases
No. Joseph P. Serrano, et al., Petitioners v. Jones & Laughlin
Steel Co. The motion for reconsideration of the order denying leave to
file a petition for writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. D-731. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Norris Clayton.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-739. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald R. Benjamin. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-748. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marvin Juron. It is or-
dered that Marvin Juron, of Deerfield, Illinois, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred.
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-749. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert A. Carter, Jr. It
is ordered that Robert A. Carter, Jr., of Columbus, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that Jonathan H. Soucek, of Cleveland, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable

MONDAY, JANUARY 9, 1989
291
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-751. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brian A. Eberstein. It is
ordered that Brian A. Eberstein, of Dallas, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 115, Original. State of Arkansas, Plaintiff v. State of Oklahoma.
The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is denied.

No. 88-5803. In Re Joseph and Irene Milkowski, Petitioners. The
motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioners are allowed until January 30, 1989, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983),
we would deny the petition for a writ of mandamus and/or prohibition
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 87-1703. F. Dale Robertson, Chief of the Forest Service, et al.,
Petitioners v. Methow Valley Citizens Council, et al.; and
No. 87-1704. John O. Marsh, Jr., Secretary of the Army, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Oregon Natural Resources Council, et al. Argued by Mr. So-
licitor General Charles Fried for the petitioners and by Mr. David A.
Bricklin for the respondents.
No. 87-1716. Granfinanciera, S.A., et al., Petitioners v. Paul C.
Nordberg, Creditor Trustee for the Estate of Chase & Sanborn Cor-
poration, etc. Argued by Mr. Adam Lawrence for the petitioners and
by Mr. Laurence Tribe for the respondent.
No. 87-1437. Melvin R. Blanton and Mark D. Fraley, Petitioners v.
City of North Las Vegas, Nevada. Argued by Mr. John J. Graves, Jr.,
for the petitioners and by Mr. Mark L. Zalaoras for the respondent.
No. 87-1020. Paul S. Davis, Appellant v. Michigan Department of
Treasury. Argued by Mr. Paul S. Davis for the appellant, by Mr. Mi-
chael K. Kellogg for the United States, as amicus curiae, supporting
appellant, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Thomas L. Casey for
the appellee.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 10, 1989
327
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-6325. Donald Ray Perry, Petitioner v. William D. Leeke,
Commissioner, South Carolina Department of Corrections, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Justice Kennedy concurring in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Mar-
shall with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 87-56. Javan Owens and Daniel G. Lessard, Petitioners v. Tom
U. U. Okure. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Marshall.
No. 87-826. Jerome F. Goldberg and Robert McTigue, Appellants .
Roger D. Sweet, Director, Illinois Department of Revenue, et al.; and
No. 87–1101. GTE Sprint Communications Corporation, Appellant 1.
Roger D. Sweet, Director, Illinois Department of Revenue, et al. Ap-
peals from the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in
part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia concur-
ring in the judgment.

No. 87-1031. G. P. Reed, Petitioner v. United Transportation Union,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Scalia concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice White.

Company, Appellants v. David M. Barasch, etc., et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom Justice White and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun.
