(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 17, 1989
331
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.".
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1818. Robert E. Badham, et al., Appellants v. March Fong
Eu, Secretary of State of California, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Northern District of California. The judg-
ment is affirmed. The Chief Justice, Justice Stevens and Justice Ken-
nedy would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 88-806. Merlino Enterprises, Inc., Appellant 2. Morris Thomp-
son, Administrator of the Estate of Frieda Sousa. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Connecticut. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. The Chief Justice would note probable ju-
risdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 88-809. Tommy Davis, et ux., Appellants v. DeChiaro Limited
Partnership, et al. Appeal from the Court of Special Appeals of Mary-
land. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 88-836. Julia McCain Lampkin Asam, Appellant . Robert J.
Shapiro, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-838. Reuben Nieves, Appellant . Marina Gardens No. 1,
Inc. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5910. Gregg Tallman, Appellant . Dorothy Kelley. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.

332
TUESDAY, JANUARY 17, 1989
No. 88-5959. Mitchell Williams, Appellant v. Planned Parenthood
Association of the Atlanta Area, et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-5816. Louis T. Frigard, etc., Appellant v. Regents of the Uni-
versity of California, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-42. Donald Joseph Clift, et al., Petitioners 2. International
Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement
Workers of America (UAW), et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit for further consideration in light of Reed v. United Transporta-
tion Union, 488 U.S. — (1989).
No. 87-1456. International Union of Operating Engineers Local 660,
Petitioner v. Edward C. Hester, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Reed v. United
Transportation Union, 488 U.S. — (1989).
No. 88-349. Federal Labor Relations Authority, Petitioner v. United
States Department of Agriculture, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of the "routine uses"
published at 53 Fed. Reg. 39629 (Department of Agriculture) and 53
Fed. Reg. 44513 (Defense Mapping Agency).
No. 88-5938. Duane W. Sanders, Petitioner 1. Harold W. Clarke,
Warden, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certio-
rari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Penson v. Ohio, 488 U.S. - . (1988).

TUESDAY, JANUARY 17, 1989
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
333
No. A-471. Charles F. Darlington, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-752. In the Matter of Disbarment of Perry Sanford Albin. It is
ordered that Perry Sanford Albin, of Newman, Illinois, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-753. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Reaves, Jr. It is
ordered that Frank Reaves, Jr., of Lexington, Kentucky, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-754. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Hartman. It is
ordered that Richard Hartman, of Greenwich, Connecticut, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-755. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald J. McKay. It is
ordered that Ronald J. McKay, of McKeesport, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-756. In the Matter of Disbarment of Patrick Clark McClurkin.
It is ordered that Patrick Clark McClurkin, of Chicago, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-757. In the Matter of Disbarment of Anthony Joseph Sacco. It
is ordered that Anthony Joseph Sacco, of Timonium, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-758. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mark A. Silverman. It is
ordered that Mark A. Silverman, of Selden, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

Committee Chairman. etc., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until Febru-
ary 7, 1989, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule
45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of
this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun,
dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1989
347
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-7028. John M. Mistretta, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 87-1904. United States, Petitioner v. John M. Mistretta. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit before judgment. Judgment of the United States District Court
for the Western District of Missouri affirmed. Opinion by Justice Black-
mun. Justice Brennan joins in the opinion except for footnote No. 11.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 86-1940. Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, et al.,
Petitioners v. Edward Lynn. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment.
Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 87-1303. Allegheny Pittsburgh Coal Company, Petitioner 2.
County Commission of Webster County, West Virginia; and
No. 87-1310. East Kentucky Energy Corporation, et al., Petitioners
v. County Commission of Webster County, West Virginia. On writs of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. Judgment
reversed and cases remanded to the Supreme Court for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the
Chief Justice.
ADMISSION TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTION
Applicant
Mark Scott Roberts
City and State
Movant
Fullerton, CA
William E.
Dannemeyer
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 87-1614. John W. Martin, et al., Petitioners . Robert K. Wilks,
et al.

348
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1989
No. 87–1639. Personnel Board of Jefferson County, Alabama, et al.,
Petitioners v. Robert K. Wilks, et al.; and
No. 87-1668. Richard Arrington, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. Robert K.
Wilks, et al. Argued by Mr. James P. Alexander for the petitioners in
Nos. 87-1639 and 87-1668, by Mr. Robert D. Joffe for the petitioners in
No. 87-1614, by Mr. Raymond P. Fitzpatrick, Jr., for the private re-
spondents, and by Mr. Thomas W. Merrill for the federal respondents.
No. 87-1816. Paul Green, Petitioner v. Bock Laundry Machine Com-
pany. Argued by Mr. Joseph M. Melillo for the petitioner and by Mr.
Thomas D. Caldwell, Jr., for the respondent.
No. 87-1815. Kentucky, Department of Corrections, et al., Petition-
ers v. James M. Thompson, et al. Argued by Mrs. Barbara Willett
Jones for the petitioners and by Mr. Joseph S. Elder, II, for the
respondents.
No. 87-1387. Wards Cove Packing Company, Inc., et al., Petitioners
v. Frank Atonio, et al. Argued by Mr. Douglas M. Fryer for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. Abraham A. Arditi for the respondents.
✗
Adjourned until Monday, January 23, 1989 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JANUARY 20, 1989
348A
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Court convened at 11 a.m. in the West Conference Room of the
Supreme Court Building and the Chief Justice said:
"The Court will take a recess to attend the inauguration of the Presi-
dent of the United States."
The oath of office was administered to Vice President Quayle by
Justice O'Connor. The oath of office was administered to President
Bush by the Chief Justice.
Adjourned until Monday, January 23, 1989 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1989
349
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, and Justice
Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-1613. Public Service Company of New Hampshire, Appellant
2. New Hampshire. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hamp-
shire. The motion of Official Committee of Equity Security Holders of
Public Service Company of New Hampshire for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Official Committee of Unse-
cured Creditors of Public Service Company of New Hampshire for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a properly presented federal question.
No. 88-130. Western Union Corporation, Appellant . Indiana De-
partment of Revenue. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Indiana,
First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 88-898. Lee Lewis Cohen and Terry George Ruger, Appellants
2. Pennsylvania. Appeal from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Har-
risburg Office. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 88-893. Glen Walker, et al., Appellants v. Valley National Bank
of Des Moines, Iowa, etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Iowa. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 88-5054. James W. Sullivan, Appellant . Katherine J. Sullivan.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-6040. Faye Ann (Flores) McCabe, Appellant 1. Frances M.
Dias, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appel-
late District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.

350
MONDAY, JANUARY 23. 1989
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1384. Laurel C. Thomas, Petitioner v. Walter Shipka. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Owens
v. Okure, 488 U.S. - (1989).
No. 88-550. United States, Petitioner v. Raul Chavez Sanchez. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Mistretta v. United States, 488 U.S. (1989).

The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.

tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-
gency executed by the petitioner is granted.

Disbarment order entered.

barment order entered.
No. D-760. In the Matter of Disbarment of Grace M. Wallis. It is or-
dered that Grace M. Wallis, of Mill Bay, British Columbia, Canada, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring her to show cause why she
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

ham. It is ordered that Frederick Townley Graham, of San Rafael, Cali-
fornia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

352
MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1989
No. 88-5977. Curtis Wrenn, Petitioner v. Richard Thornburgh, At-
torney General of the United States, et al. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until
February 13, 1989, within which to pay the docketing fee required by
Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
No. 88-6204. John M. Branion, Jr., Petitioner v. Richard B. Gramly,
Warden. The motion of petitioner to expedite consideration of the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is denied.

No. 88-309. Wyoming, Petitioner v. United States, et al. The peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wyoming is
granted limited to Question 2 presented by the petition.

OPINIONS
No. 87-1190. United States, Petitioner . Ray C. Broce and Broce
Construction Co., Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring
opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun
with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 87-998. City of Richmond, Appellant 2. J. A. Croson Company.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Justice O'Connor announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I,
III-B, and IV, an opinion with respect to Part II, in which the Chief
Justice and Justice White join, and an opinion with respect to Parts
III-A and V, in which the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice Ken-
nedy join. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and concurring
in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 87-764. Florida, Petitioner . Michael A. Riley. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceeding not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Justice White announced the judgment
of the Court and delivered an opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice
Scalia and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with

364
MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1989
whom Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun.
No. 87-1224. Mark H. Oring, Appellant v. State Bar of California.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a properly presented federal question. Opinion per curiam
announced by the Chief Justice.
No. 87-1372. Argentine Republic, Petitioner v. Amerada Hess Ship-
ping Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun concurring in part with whom Justice Marshall joins.
Х
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 21, 1989 at 10 o'clock.
No. A-580. Theodore Robert Bundy, Applicant v. Richard L.
Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections;
No. A-585. Theodore Robert Bundy, Applicant v. Florida; and
No. A-586. Theodore Robert Bundy, Applicant v. Richard L.
Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The applica-
tions for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Kennedy and by him referred to the Court are denied. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice
Blackmun would grant the applications for stay in Nos. A-580 and
A-586. Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay in
No. A-580.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1989
369
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-5890. In Re Jessie McDonald. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. The petitioner is allowed
until until March 14, 1989, within which to pay the docketing fee re-
quired by Rule 45(a) and to submit a peititon in compliance with Rule 33
of the Rules of this Court. We also direct the Clerk not to accept any
further petitions from petitioner for extraordinary writs pursuant to 28
U.S.C. §§ 1651(a), 2241 and 2254(a), unless he pays the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a), and submits his petition in compliance with
Rule 33. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan
with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Stevens
join.

light of United States v. Broce, 488 U.S. — (1989).

consideration in light of Owens v. Okure, 488 U.S.

No. 88-5853. John F. Corch, Petitioner U. Director, Office of Work-
ers' Compensation Programs, United States Department of Labor. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until March 14, 1989, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and Jus-
tice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Her
ald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ
of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.

Robert T. Goode, Jr. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Virginia granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one
hour is allotted for oral argument.

tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.

granted.

allegation that a state statute is preempted by a federal statute is cogni-

OPINIONS
No. 87-1201. Myles Osterneck and Guy-Kenneth Osterneck, etc., Pe-
titioners. Ernst & Whinney. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Kennedy.
No. 87-1054. Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, et al., Petition-
ers Richard Bruch, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed in

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1989
423
part, reversed in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment.
No. 87-1206. Kathryn Isabella Mesa and Shabbir A. Ebrahim, aka
Shabbir Azam, Petitioners 1. California. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 87-1346. Bonito Boats, Inc., Petitioner . Thunder Craft Boats,
Inc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 87-470. Fort Wayne Books, Inc., Petitioner . Indiana, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana; and
No. 87-614. Ronald W. Sappenfield, et al., Petitioners 1. Indiana. On
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District. The
judgment in No. 87-470 is reversed and the case is remanded to the
Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. The judgment in No. 87-614 is affirmed and the case
is remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part and concurring in the judg-
ment. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and dissenting in
part. Opinion by Justice Stevens dissenting in No. 87-614 and concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part in No. 87-470 with whom Justice.
Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 87-1485. Arthur J. Blanchard, Petitioner . James Bergeron, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring
in part and concurring in the judgment.
No. 87-1245. Texas Monthly, Inc., Appellant r. Bob Bullock, Comp-
troller of Public Accounts of the State of Texas, et al. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Texas, Third District. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Justice Brennan announced the judg-
ment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which Justice Marshall
and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment

424
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1989
with whom Justice O'Connor joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia
with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy join.

No. 87-1602. Ronald D. Castille, etc., et al., Petitioners 2. Michael
Peoples. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court.
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 87-5259. Frank Dean Teague, Petitioner 1. Michael Lane, Direc-
tor, Illinois Department of Corrections, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Justice O'Connor announced the judgment of the Court and
delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, and III,
and an opinion with respect to Parts IV and V, with whom the Chief
Justice, Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice
White concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment with whom Justice Blackmun joins as to Part I. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 87-5677. Warren Lee Harris, Petitioner. Marvin Reed, War-
den, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Kennedy.
No. 87-1043. United States, Petitioner. Ron Pair Enterprises, Inc.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals.
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor
with whom Justice Brennan. Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens join.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-715. Forrest H. Burleson, Appellant r. Jacqueline D. Burle-
son. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California. Third Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 88-5990. Elaine Robinson, Appellant 1. United States Depart-
ment of Education. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction.
No. 88-6242. Elaine L. Robinson, Appellant . English Department
of the University of Pennsylvania, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-1784. Massachusetts, Petitioner 1. Stephen J. Gray, Trustee
in Bankruptcy of Newbury Cafe, Inc., dba 29 Newbury. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit for further consideration in light of United States
v. Ron Pair Enterprises, Inc., 489 U.S. — (1989).
No. 87-2070. Chester DeGeare, et al.. Petitioners . Slattery Group.
Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company x. Bruch,
489 U.S.. (1989).
-

430
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1989
No. 87-6063. David Meadows, Petitioner . Manfred G. Holland,
Warden. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Harris v. Reed, 489 U.S. ——— (1989).
No. 87-7320. Lawrence J. Sparks, Petitioner . Dale Foltz, Warden.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Harris v. Reed, 489 U.S. (1989).
-
No. 88-163. Combustion Engineering, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Arsenio C. Saporito, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
for further consideration in light of Firestone Tire and Rubber Com-
pany v. Bruch, 489 U.S. (1989).
No. 88-729. Robert Rowe, et al., Petitioners . Allied Chemical
Hourly Employees' Pension Plan, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Firestone Tire and Rubber
Company v. Bruch, 489 U.S. (1989).

ment order entered.
No. D-735. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter Richard Stoll. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-771. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mario Biaggi. It is or-
dered that Mario Biaggi, of New York, New York, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1989
431
No. 114, Original. State of Louisiana, Plaintiff r. State of Missis-
sippi, et al. The petition for rehearing and alternative motion to file a
separate complaint is denied.
No. 87-2127. American Foreign Service Association, et al., Appel-
lants Steven Garfinkel, Director, Information Security Oversight Of-
fice, et al. The motion of United States Senate for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae, out-of-time, is granted. The motion of Speaker and
Leadership Group for leave to file a brief as amici curiae, out-of-time,
is granted.
No. 88–148. Southern Natural Gas Company, Petitioner 1. Joseph F.
Fritz, et al. The motion of petitioner to defer consideration of the peti-
tion for certiorari is granted.
No. 88-293. Community for Creative Non-Violence, et al., Petition-
ers . James Earl Reid. The motion of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts
Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 88-309. Wyoming, Petitioner 1. United States, et al. The motion
of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 88-1105. Curtis Guidry, Petitioner 1. Sheet Metal Workers Na-
tional Pension Fund, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 88-6265. James Carlson, et ux., Petitioners . County of Henne-
pin, Minnesota, et al. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioners are allowed until March 20, 1989,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1989
No. 88-49. Calvin Berry, III, et al., Petitioners . City of Dallas, et
al. The motion of Citizens For Decency Through Law, Inc. for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae in No. 87-2012 is granted. The petition for
a writ of certiorari in No. 87-2012 to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit is granted limited to Questions I, II and III
presented by the petition. The petition for a writ of certiorari in
No. 87-2051 to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
is granted limited to Questions 1 and 2 presented by the petition. The
petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit in No. 88-49 is granted. The cases are consolidated
and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-548. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Independent
Federation of Flight Attendants. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Bren-
nan joins as to Parts I and II.
No. 86-1088. City of Canton, Ohio, Petitioner 1. Geraldine Harris,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice Bren-
nan. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 87-121. Richard L. Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, and Robert A. Butterworth, Attorney General of Florida,
Petitioners Aubrey Dennis Adams, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice.
White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens join.
No. 87–1064. United States, Petitioner 1. Philip George Stuart. Sr.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Kennedy con-
curring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
O'Connor joins. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment.

Merrill for the appellant and by Mr. Richard McMillan, Jr., for the
appellee.
No. 87–1945. William A. Frazee, Appellant 1. Illinois Department of
Employment Security, et al. Argued by Mr. David A. French for the
appellant and by Mr. Robert J. Ruiz for the appellees.
No. 87-1848. City of Dallas, et al., Petitioners 1. Charles M.
Stanglin, Individually, and dba Twilight Skating Rink. Argued by Mr.
Craig Lee Hopkins for the petitioners and by Mr. Daniel J. Sheehan,
Jr., for the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, March 6, 1989 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 6. 1989
449
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, and Justice
Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-1860. William G. Milliken, et al., Appellants 1. Michigan
Road Builders Association, Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 88-977. Colorado-Ute Electric Association, Inc., et al., Appel-
lants v. Public Utilities Commission of Colorado, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a prop-
erly presented federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87–1001. H. K. Porter Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Metropolitan
Dade County, Florida, and John A. Dyer, etc. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of City of
Richmond v. J. A. Croson Company, 488 U.S. — (1989). Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens
would deny certiorari.
No. 88-802. Frederick Smith, etc., et al., Petitioners 1. Kathleen
Stoneking. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The motion of petitioners to consoli-
date this case with No. 88-1350, Smith v. Sowers, is denied. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit for further consideration in light of DeShaney v. Winnebago
County Department of Social Services, 489 U.S. (1989).
-
No. 88-816. City of New Kensington, et al., Petitioners 1. Mamie
Horton, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-

450
MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1989
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of DeShaney v. Winnebago County Department
of Social Services, 489 U.S. (1989).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. John Lathen, Applicant v. United States. The application
for an extension of time within which to file a petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
-
No. . Mary Margaret Ward, et al., Petitioners . Richard W.
Freedman. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a petition for a
writ of certiorari under seal is denied.
No. A-624. Olivia Boyce, Applicant v. Israelite Bible Class, Inc. The
application for stay presented to Justice Stevens and by him referred to
the Court is denied.
No. 112, Original. State of Wyoming, Plaintiff v. State of Oklahoma.
It is ordered that the Hon. Philip W. Tone, of Chicago, Illinois, be ap-
pointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix the time and
conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent
proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoe-
nas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may
deem necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit
such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other expenses, includ-
ing travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the par-
ties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
No. 88-333. Alabama, Petitioner v. James Lewis Smith. The motion
for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Delores
Boyd, Esq., of Montgomery, Alabama, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the respondent in this case.
No. 88-412. Martin W. Hoffman, Trustee, Petitioner 1. Connecticut
Department of Income Maintenance, et al. The motion of INSLAW,
Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 88-515. Sable Communications of California, Inc., Appellant 1.
Federal Communications Commission, et al.; and
No. 88-525. Federal Communications Commission, et al., Appellants
1. Sable Communications of California, Inc. The motion of United
States Catholic Conference for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is

MONDAY, MARCH 6, 1989
451
granted. The motion of American Family Association, Inc. for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Morality in
Media, Inc. for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 88-605. William L. Webster, Attorney General of Missouri, et
al., Appellants v. Reproductive Health Services, et al. The motion of
James Joseph Lynch, Jr., for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of National Legal Foundation for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Legal Defense for Un-
born Children for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The
motion of Alan Ernest for leave to represent children unborn and born.
alive is denied.
No. 88-1083. John Doe Agency and John Doe Government Agency,
Petitioners v. John Doe Corporation. The motion of respondent to ad-
vance oral argument is denied.
No. 88-1281. Alex Ngiraingas, et al., Petitioners . Francisco Q.
Sanchez, etc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States. Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 88-6352. Richard R. Burkart, Petitioner v. Post-Browning, Inc.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Petitioner is allowed until March 27, 1989, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-6635. Harold Glenn Williams, Petitioner 2. Ralph Kemp,
Warden. The application of the Attorney General of Georgia to vacate
the stay of execution granted by the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred
to the Court is denied.

No. 88-5561. Melvin Gilmore, Petitioner v. Director, Office of Work-
ers' Compensation Programs, U. S. Department of Labor;
No. 88-5910. Gregg Tallman, Appellant v. Dorothy Kelley;
No. 88-5942. Dorsey Lee Robertson, Petitioner v. City of Eunice,
New Mexico; and
No. 88-5960. Steven E. Dodrill, Petitioner v. Arthur Tate, Jr., Su-
perintendent, Chillicothe Correctional Institute. The petitions for re-
hearing are denied.
ORDER
It is ordered that Shelley L. Dowling be appointed Librarian of the
Court to succeed Stephen G. Margeton, effective January 15, 1989, and
that she take the oath of office as required by statute.

CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 88-6721. Albert Ray Beam, Petitioner . Idaho. The application
to continue stay of execution of death warrant presented to Justice.
O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Idaho is denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 15, 1989
471
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-727. Jonas H. Whitmore, Individually and as Next Friend of
Ronald Gene Simmons, Applicant v. Arkansas. The application for stay
of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Blackmun and by
him referred to the Court is granted pending the timely filing and dis-
position by this Court of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automati-
cally. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay
shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1989
473
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-844. Willard G. Chrisman, Appellant . Times Mirror Com-
pany. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 88-1013. Raymond DeLeo, et ux., Appellants v. Anthony A.
Nunes, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 88-6386. Lynn A. Jenkins, Appellant v. United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 88-6471. Howard Crim, Jr., Appellant 1. Terry L. Morris, Su-
perintendent, Southern Ohio Correctional Facility, et al. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
ORDERS IN Pending CaSES
No. A-695. Michigan Citizens for an Independent Press, et al., Ap-
plicants Richard Thornburgh. Attorney General of the United
States, et al. The application for stay presented to Justice Brennan and
by him referred to the Court is denied. The order heretofore entered
March 4, 1989. by Justice Brennan is vacated. Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens would grant the application. Justice White took no part
in the consideration or decision of this application.
No. D-536. In the Matter of Lee Gilson Lovett. The motion to vacate
the order of disbarment is denied.

474
MONDAY, MARCH 20, 1989
No. D-751. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brian A. Eberstein. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-772. In the Matter of Disbarment of Rembert Thomas Brown.
It is ordered that Rembert Thomas Brown, of San Diego, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-773. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Lee Gagen. It is
ordered that William Lee Gagen, of Lebanon, Illinois, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-774. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Roger Gunder-
man. It is ordered that James Roger Gunderman, of Buffalo, New
York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-775. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Hardin Graves. It
is ordered that David Hardin Graves, of Houston, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

TUESDAY, MARCH 21, 1989
501
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-1555. Samuel K. Skinner, Secretary of Transportation, et al.,
Petitioners v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall
with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 86-1879. National Treasury Employees Union, et al., Petitioners
v. William Von Raab, Commissioner, United States Customs Service.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth.
Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, vacated in part and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice Stevens joins.
No. 87-248. Georgia Brower, Individually and as Administrator of
the Estate of William James Caldwell (Brower), Deceased, et al., Peti-
tioners. County of Inyo, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opin-
ion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 87-996. Coit Independence Joint Venture, Petitioner 1. Federal
Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, as Receiver of FirstSouth,
F.A. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Blackmun con-
curring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice
Scalia concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 27, 1989
507
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Justice Brennan is not present today due to a death in his family. He
will participate in the decision of the cases argued today on the basis of
the briefs and transcripts of argument."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-1011. James D. Harman, et al., Appellants v. Elizabeth Dole,
Secretary of Labor, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition.
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. James McConico, Jr., Petitioner 2. Polly Conradi. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari, out-of-
time, is denied.

Disbarment order entered.

ment order entered.

barment order entered.

MONDAY, MARCH 27, 1989
No. D-764. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Pryor Smith.
Disbarment order entered.
No. 88-6494. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner u. Lawrence P. Benson, et
al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until April 17, 1989, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-6497. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner 1. Department of Mental
Health of Ohio. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until April 17, 1989, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice.
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the rea-
sons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-6533. Frederick C. Fermin, Petitioner 2. Commodity Futures.
Trading Commission, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until April 17,
1989, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissent-
ing: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S.
928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 88-926. North Dakota, et al., Appellants 1. United States. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. In
this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 88-6222. Scott Wayne Blystone, Petitioner u. Pennsylvania. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District, are granted limited to Question II presented by the
petition.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 28, 1989
521
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Justice Brennan is not present today due to a death in his family. He
will participate in the decision of the cases argued today on the basis of
the briefs and transcripts of argument."
OPINIONS
No. 87-1020. Paul S. Davis, Appellant v. Michigan Department of
Treasury. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeal for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 87-1905. Midland Asphalt Corporation and Albert C. Litteer,
Petitioners v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Scalia.
No. 87-1759. Texas State Teachers Association, et al., Petitioners v.
Garland Independent School District, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further deter-
mination of a reasonable attorney's fee consistent with the principles es-
tablished by our decision in Hensley v. Eckerhart, 461 U.S. 424 (1983).
Opinion by Justice O'Connor.

MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1989
525
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-2118. Alexander M. Rojas, et al., Appellants u. Victoria Inde-
pendent School District, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Texas. The judgment is affirmed.
Justice White and Justice Scalia would note probable jurisdiction and
set the case for oral argument.
No. 88-1340. Charles F. Wishart, et ux., Appellants r. Leslie M.
Bates and Randall A. Bates. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Flor-
ida. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION:
No. 87-255. Magd E. Zohdi, et al., Petitioners 1. Federal Savings
and Loan Insurance Corporation, as Receiver of Sun Belt Federal
Bank, F. S. B., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded.
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further.
consideration in light of Coit Independence Joint Venture v. Federal
Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, 489 U.S. (1989).
-
No. 87-1706. Andrew E. Jenkins, Superintendent of Schools, et al.,
Petitioners. Juanita M. Jones. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated.
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit for further consideration in light of Skinner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, 489 U.S. — (1989) and
National Treasury Employees Union v. Von Raab. 489 U.S.
(1989). Justice Stevens would deny certiorari.

526
MONDAY, APRIL 3. 1989
No. 88-557. Michigan, Petitioner v. Reginald D. Leigh. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Michigan for further con-
sideration in light of Arizona v. Youngblood, 488 U.S. (1989). Jus-
tice Stevens would deny certiorari.
-
No. 88-1121. Stephen G. Bradley, Sr., Stephen M. Bradley, Jr., Re-
gina Bradley and Timothy Buckley, Petitioners . United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light
of the position presently asserted by the Acting Solicitor General in the
Brief for the United States filed March 8, 1989. The Chief Justice, Jus-
tice White, Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy would deny certiorari.
No. 88-1350. Frederick Smith, Individually, and as Principal, Brad-
ford Area High School, et al., Petitioners v. Judy Grove Sowers. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light
of DeShaney v. Winnebago County Department of Social Services, 489
U.S. (1989).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-761. Miguel A. Gargallo, Applicant 1. Quick & Reilly Clear-

referred to the Court is denied.

pendix is granted.

of the Acting Solicitor General for divided argument is granted.

Department of Income Maintenance, et al. The motion of the Acting So-
licitor General for divided argument is granted.

motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that

MONDAY, APRIL 3. 1989
527
Brian Reed Phillips, Esquire, of Everett, Washington, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 88-605. William L. Webster, Attorney General of Missouri, et
al., Appellants v. Reproductive Health Services, et al. The motion of
Robert Packwood, et al. for leave to participate in oral argument as
amici curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral ar-
gument is denied.
No. 88-5890. In Re Jessie McDonald, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 88-931. Lawrence H. Crandon, et al, Petitioners v. United
States; and
No. 88-938. Boeing Company, Inc., Petitioner v. United States. Pe-
titions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit are granted. The cases are consolidated and a total
of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 88-1182. Baltimore City Department of Social Services, Peti-
tioner v. Jacqueline Bouknight; and
No. 88-6651. Maurice M., Petitioner v. Jacqueline Bouknight. The
motion of respondent Jacqueline Bouknight for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petitions for writs of certiorari to the
Court of Appeals of Maryland are granted limited to the following
questions:
1. Does a court order directing a parent to produce her previously
abused infant son compel incriminating testimony in violation of the
parent's Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination?
2. Even if the Fifth Amendment privilege is implicated by a court.
order to produce a child, is the privilege overcome by the important so-
cietal interest in protecting children in jeopardy of serious injury?
The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.

OPINIONS
No. 87-453. Amerada Hess Corporation, et al., Appellants r. Direc-
tor, Division of Taxation, New Jersey Department of the Treasury; and
No. 87-464. Texaco, Inc. and Tenneco Oil Company. Appellants
Director, Division of Taxation, New Jersey Department of the Treas-
ury. Appeals from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Justice Scalia concur-
ring in the judgment. Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 87-980. Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians. Appellant . Orrey
Curtiss Holyfield, et ux., J. B., Natural Mother and W. J., Natural Fa-
ther. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice

540
MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1989
Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 87-1865. Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, as
Receiver for Manning Savings and Loan Association, Petitioner v. Har-
old J. Ticktin, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens announced
by the Chief Justice.
No. 87-1295. United States, Petitioner v. Andrew Sokolow. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with
whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 87-1848. City of Dallas, et al., Petitioners 2. Charles M.
Stanglin, Individually, and dba Twilight Skating Rink. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fifth District. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the
Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment
with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
Adjourned until Monday, April 17, 1989 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, APRIL 7, 1989
545
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 88-493. University of Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Equal Employ-
ment Opportunity Commission. The order entered December 12, 1988,
granting the petition for a writ of certiorari is amended to read: "The
petition for a writ of certiorari is granted limited to Question 1 pre-
sented by the petition." This case is removed from the calendar for ar-
gument on April 18, 1989. The case will be argued during the October
Term 1989.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1989
547
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-6494. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner t. Lawrence P. Benson, et
al.; and
No. 88-6497. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner 1. Department of Mental
Health of Ohio. On motions for leave to proceed in forma pauperis. The
Clerk of the Court is directed not to accept any further filings from
petitioner in which he seeks leave to proceed in forma pauperis under
this Court's Rule 46, unless the affidavit submitted with the filing indi-
cates that petitioner's financial condition has substantially changed
from that reflected in the affidavits submitted by him in the cases, 489
U.S. (1989). Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice.
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens.
-
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-1491. Keith M. Rhinehart, et al., Appellants . The Seattle
Times, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Washington, Division
1. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 88-6255. Linda K. Shaffer. Appellant . Department of Social
Services. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 88-6630. Bonnie Marie H.. a Minor, Appellant. Richard
Hannan, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Sixth Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly pre-
sented federal question.

548
MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1989
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
.
No. 88-1366. Wayne A. Simmons, et al., Petitioners . Irma Jean Pe-
rez. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of City of Canton, Ohio v. Harris, 489 U.S. (1989).
No. 88-1395. Municipal Court of the Southeast Judicial District,
County of Los Angeles, et al., Petitioners r. Alva Gutierrez. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The motion of U. S. English Foundation, Inc., et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit with in-
structions to
to dismiss the appeal as moot. United States v.
Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36 (1950).

No. D-776. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mark Eugene Werner,
II. It is ordered that Mark Eugene Werner, II, of Baltimore, Mary-
land, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-777. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Cooper. It is or-
dered that Michael Cooper, of Arlington Heights, Illinois, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, APRIL 18. 1989
577
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87–1055. Elisa Chan, et al., Petitioners . Korean Air Lines,
Ltd. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Scalia. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment with
whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Stevens join.
No. 88-32. Massachusetts, Petitioner . Richard N. Morash. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Stevens.
No. 87-1862. California, et al., Appellants 1. ARC America Corpora-
tion, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 87-2127. American Foreign Service Association, et al., Appel-
lants : Steven Garfinkel, Director. Information Security Oversight Of-
fice, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the District
Court for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 24, 1989
581
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-980. Frank R. Eckles, dba Riverview Marina, Appellant v.
Oregon, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oregon. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-750. Pan American World Airways, Inc., Petitioner v.
Ernesto Serio Pampin Lopez, Individually and as Administrator of the
Estate of Sara E. Lopez, Deceased, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Chan v. Korean Air
Lines, Ltd., 490 U.S. - (1989).
No. 88-6056. Neftali Perez, Petitioner. Everett Jones, Superin-
tendent, Great Meadow Correctional Facility. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit for further consideration in light of Harris v. Reed, 489
U.S. (1989).
ORDERS IN Pending Cases
No. 74, Original. State of Georgia, Plaintiff r. State of South Caro-
lina. The second and final report of the Special Master is received and
ordered filed. Exceptions to the Report, with supporting briefs, may be
filed by the parties within 45 days. Reply briefs to such Exceptions may
be filed within 30 days.

582
MONDAY, APRIL 24. 1989
No. 88-309. Wyoming, Petitioner v. United States, et al. The motion
of respondents Shoshone Tribe and Northern Arapaho Tribe to strike
brief of respondents Bradford Bath, et al. is denied.
No. 88-1480. Bob Reves, et al., Petitioners 1. Arthur Young & Co.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 88-6732. Thomas H. Lashley, et ux., Petitioners v. First Na-
tional Bank of Live Oak. The motion of petitioners for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioners are allowed until May 15, 1989,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 88-1319. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner . Indi-
anapolis Power & Light Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
No. 88-1076. J. Paul Preseault, et ux., Petitioners 1. Interstate
Commerce Commission, et al. The motion of Pacific Legal Foundation
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Na-
tional Association of Reversionary Property Owners for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
No. 88-1150. Missouri, et al., Petitioners u. Kalima Jenkins, et al.
The motion of National Taxpayers Union, et al. for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted limited to Ques-
tion 2 presented by the petition. The parties are directed to brief also
whether the petition for a writ of certiorari is timely filed.
No. 88-1264. James Saffle, Warden, et al., Petitioners r. Robyn Le-
roy Parks. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
No. 88-6546. Albert Duro, Petitioner 1. Edward Reina, Chief of Po-
lice, Salt River Department of Public Safety, Salt River Pima-Maricopa
Indian Community, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in

MONDAY, APRIL 24. 1989
583
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

TUESDAY, APRIL 25, 1989
595
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-2098. Samuel K. Skinner, Secretary of Transportation, Appel-
lant . Mid-America Pipeline Company. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the District Court for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice.
O'Connor.
No. 87-1327. Cotton Petroleum Corporation, et al., Appellants
New Mexico, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall
join.
No. 87-1956. Anthony M. Frank, Postmaster General of the United
States, et al., Appellants 1. Minnesota Newspaper Association, Inc.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Minne-
sota. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the District Court to dis-
miss the portions of the complaint remaining at issue on this appeal.
United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36, 39-40 (1950). Opinion
per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Justice White and Justice Marshall dissent.
