pellants . Wayne L. Millsap, et al. Argued by Mr. Kevin M. O'Keefe
for the appellants and by Mr. Simon Bolivar Buckner, IV, for the
appellees.
ORDERS
Ordered:
1. That the Bankruptcy Rules be, and they are hereby, amended by
including therein an amendment to Bankruptcy Rule 9006(a).
2. That the foregoing change in the Bankruptcy Rules shall take ef-
fect on August 1, 1989 and shall govern all proceedings in bankruptcy
cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all
proceedings in bankruptcy cases then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendment to the Bankruptcy Rules in

TUESDAY, APRIL 25, 1989
597
accordance with the provisions of Section 2075 of Title 28, United
States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure be, and they are
hereby, amended by including therein amendments to Appellate Rules.
1(a), 3(a), 26(a), 27(a), 28(g) and new Rules 6 and 26.1, and a new Form.
5.
2. That the foregoing additions to and changes in the Federal Rules
of Appellate Procedure, shall take effect on December 1, 1989 and shall
govern all proceedings in appellate actions thereafter commenced and,
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings in appellate actions then
pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing additions to and changes in the rules of
appellate procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United
States District Courts be, and they are hereby, amended by including
therein amendments to Criminal Rules ll(c), 32(a) and (c), 32.1(a) and
(b), 40(d) and 41(e).
2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 1989 and shall govern all
proceedings in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, all proceedings in criminal cases then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 26, 1989
599
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 88-605. William L. Webster, Attorney General of Missouri, et
al., Appellants v. Reproductive Health Services, et al. Argued by Mr.
William L. Webster for the appellants, by Mr. Charles Fried for the
United States, as amicus curiae, supporting appellants, by special leave
of Court, and by Mr. Frank Susman for the appellees.
No. 87-6997. Eugene John Carella, Appellant 2. California. Argued
by Mr. Christopher D. Cerf for the appellant, pro hac vice, by special
leave of Court, and by Mr. Arnold T. Guminski for the appellee.
No. 88-420. Jimmy Jones, Superintendent, Missouri Training Center
for Men at Moberly, Petitioner v. Larry P. Thomas. Argued by Mr.
Stephen D. Hawke for the petitioner and by Mr. Springfield Baldwin
for the respondent.

Adjourned until Monday, May 1, 1989 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 1, 1989
601
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, and Justice
Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-773. Rodey, Dickason, Sloan, Akin & Robb, P. A., Appellant
v. Revenue Division of the Department of Taxation of New Mexico. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of New Mexico. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-1290. David R. Benjamin, et al., Petitioners 2. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Midland Asphalt Corporation v. United States, 489 U.S.
(1989).
-

Blackmun dissents.

thews. Disbarment order entered.

MONDAY, ΜΑΥ 1, 1989
No. D-771. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mario Biaggi. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-782. In the Matter of Disbarment of Everett Emett Ricks, Jr.
It is ordered that Everett Emett Ricks, Jr., of Long Beach, California,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-783. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard R. Paige. It is
ordered that Richard R. Paige, of Miami, Florida, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-784. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry G. Lillback. It is
ordered that Larry G. Lillback, of Mentor, Ohio, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff . State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for approval of fees and expenses is
granted and the River Master is awarded $7,168.53 for the period Janu-
ary 1-March 31, 1989, to be paid equally by the parties.

OPINIONS
No. 87-1882. Dean Neitzke, etc., et al., Petitioners. Harry Law-
rence Williams, Sr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Jus-
tice Marshall.
No. 87-1167. Price Waterhouse, Petitioner 1. Ann B. Hopkins. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District

MONDAY, MAY 1, 1989
615
of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Justice Brennan announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an oppinion in which Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom the Chief Justice.
and Justice Scalia join.
No. 87-1490. John E. Mallard, Petitioner v. United States District
Court for the Southern District of Iowa, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun,
and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 87-1703. F. Dale Robertson, Chief of the Forest Service, et al.,
Petitioners v. Methow Valley Citizens Council, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Stevens announced by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by
Justice Brennan.
No. 87-1704. John O. Marsh, Jr., Secretary of the Army, et al., Peti-
tioners . Oregon Natural Resources Council, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Stevens announced by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MAY 3, 1989
619
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 88-7140. Aubrey Dennis Adams, Jr., Petitioner v. Richard L.
Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit is
denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall joins.



(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, MAY 11, 1989
621
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-881. Bryan S. Lankford, Applicant v. Idaho. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice O'Connor
and by her referred to the Court is granted pending the timely filing
and disposition by this Court of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 15, 1989
623
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-6811. Robert Lee Hesler, Appellant v. Cabinet for Human
Resources of Kentucky. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 88-1208. Sandia Federal Savings and Loan Association, Peti-
tioner v. Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, etc. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Coit
Independence Joint Venture v. Federal Savings and Loan Insurance
Corporation, 489 U.S. (1989).
-
No. 88-1300. Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, as
Receiver for Bohemian Savings and Loan Association, Petitioner v.
John V. Capozzi, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corpora-
tion v. Ticktin, 489 U.S. (1989).
No.. -.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
In Re Gregg Al Cramblett. The motion for leave to file a
petition for common law writ of habeas corpus and other relief is
denied.
No. -.
In Re Patricia A. Dean. The motion for an order to file a
petition for writ of habeas corpus and other relief is denied.

624
MONDAY, MAY 15, 1989
No. D-750. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jonathan H. Soucek. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-785. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mitchell David Aronson.
It is ordered that Mitchell David Aronson, of North Miami, Florida, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-786. In the Matter of Disbarment of John J. Ford, III. It is
ordered that John J. Ford, III, of San Francisco, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-787. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank G. Prantil. It is
ordered that Frank G. Prantil, of Fair Oaks, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-788. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael H. Cates. It is
ordered that Michael H. Cates, of Key West, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The second interim motion of the Special Master for com-
pensation and reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Special
Master is awarded $94,801.10 to be paid 40% by Nebraska, 40% by Wy-
oming and 20% by the United States.
No. 88–124. Lynn L. Breininger, Petitioner v. Sheet Metal Workers
International Association Local Union No. 6. The motion of the Acting
Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus cu-
riae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 88-1264. James Saffle, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Robyn Le-
roy Parks. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is
ordered that Vivian O. Berger, Esq., of New York, New York, is ap-
pointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 88-1353. United States, Petitioner v. Rene Martin Verdugo-
Urquidez. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.

MONDAY, MAY 15, 1989
625
No. 88-1374. Jimmy Swaggart Ministries, Appellant v. Board of
Equalization of California. The motion of appellee to limit questions
presented for review is denied.
No. 88-6896. Charles F. Schaefer, Petitioner v. Transportation
Media, Inc., etc. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 5, 1989, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the rea-
sons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 88-6966. Victor A. Rita, Jr., Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until June 5, 1989, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983),
we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 88-1434. Elizabeth Dole, Secretary of Labor, et al., Petitioners
v. United Steelworkers of America, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 88-1512. Albert J. Ferens, et ux., Petitioners v. John Deere
Company, aka Deere & Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 88-1377. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Brian Zebley, et al. The motion of respondents
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
granted.

OPINIONS
No. 88-385. Ofelia Rodriguez de Quijas, et al., Petitioners v.
Shearson/American Express, Inc., etc. On writ of certiorari to the

MONDAY, MAY 15, 1989
649
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Black-
mun join.
No. 87-1344. Richard L. Thornburgh, Attorney General of the
United States, et al., Petitioners v. Jack Abbott, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Colum-
bia Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Justice Stevens con-
curring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall join.
No. 87-1815. Kentucky, Department of Corrections, et al., Petition-
ers v. James M. Thompson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens join.
No. 87-1383. United States, Appellant v. Irwin Halper. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the District Court for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy.
No. 87-6571. Dethorne Graham, Petitioner v. M. S. Connor, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring
in part and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall join.
No. 88-357. Norm Maleng, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Mark Edwin
Cook. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam announced
by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, MAY 18, 1989
655
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Stevens, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-903. Richard W. Boylston, etc., Applicant v. T.W. The motion
of the American Civil Liberties Union, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is denied. The application for stay presented to Justice
Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied. The order hereto-
fore entered by Justice Kennedy on May 16, 1989, is vacated.
No. A-912. Henry Willis, III, Applicant v. Walter Zant, Warden.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 22, 1989
657
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-1095. Joseph Howe, et ux., Appellants v. Norchek of New-
port, Inc., dba Woody's Wharf, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal
of California, Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1994. Richard L. Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. Robert Lawson, etc., et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Thornburgh v. Abbott, 490 U.S. - (1989).
No. 88-284. Dain Bosworth Incorporated, Petitioner v. David S.
Johnson, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals
of Minnesota. The motion of Securities Industry Association, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the Court of Appeals of Minnesota for further consideration in light
of Rodriguez de Quijas v. Shearson/American Express, Inc., 490 U.S.
(1989). Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this motion and this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. In Re Sandra Kathleen Byers, Petitioner. The motion to
order the Clerk to file a petition for writ of habeas corpus and other
relief is denied.
No. -. Phillips Petroleum Company, Petitioner v. Robert L. Gray,
et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certio-
rari, out-of-time, is denied.

658
MONDAY, MAY 22, 1989
No. A-819. Gene Crescenzi, Applicant v. Departmental Disciplinary
Committee for the First Judicial Department. The application for stay
addressed to Justice White and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-743. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph R. Carter, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-774. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Roger
Gunderman. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-789. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Joseph Guinan.
It is ordered that Michael Joseph Guinan, of Oxford, Wisconsin, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 87-1979. Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Nancy J. Schwalb and William McGlone; and
No. 88-127. Norfolk & Western Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Robert T. Goode, Jr. The motion of the Acting Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument is granted.
No. 88-1319. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Indi-
anapolis Power & Light Company. The motion of the Acting Solicitor
General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 88-6546. Albert Duro, Petitioner v. Edward Reina, Chief of Po-
lice, Salt River Department of Public Safety, Salt River Pima-Maricopa
Indian Community, et al. The motion for appointment of counsel is
granted and it is ordered that John J. Trebon, Esquire, of Flagstaff,
Arizona, is appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 88-6677. Horace Butler, Petitioner v. Kenneth D. McKellar,
Warden, et al. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it
is ordered that John H. Blume, Esquire, of Columbia, South Carolina,
is appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 88-6732. Thomas H. Lashley, et ux., Petitioners v. First Na-
tional Bank of Live Oak. The motion of petitioners for reconsideration
of order denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 88-1323. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, et al., Petitioners v. Sandra Everhart, et al. The motion of
respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit granted.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-923. Stephen Albert McCoy, Applicant v. James L. Lynaugh,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White and by him
referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Marshall. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay.

675

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1989
677
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-6066. Paul C. Hildwin, Petitioner v. Florida. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for a writ of certiorari are
granted. Judgment affirmed. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1422. Gary W. Justice, Petitioner v. John W. Dennis, etc. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Graham v. Connor, 490 U. S. (1989).
No. 87-6899. James Callwood, Petitioner v. John Questel, et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light
of Hardin v. Straub, 490 U. S. (1989).
No. 88-1581. County of Los Angeles and Ronald Black, Commander,
Los Angeles County Men's Central Jail, Petitioners v. Josefina Ca-
brales. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of City of Canton, Ohio v. Harris, 489 U. S. (1989).
Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens dissent and would deny certiorari.

678
TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1989
No. 88-5152. John Perotti, Petitioner v. Robert Carty, et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Har-
din v. Straub, 490 U. S. (1989).
No. 88-5213. Sylvester Gavin, Petitioner v. H. Gary Wells, Warden.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Maleng v. Cook, 490 U. S. — (1989).
-
No. 88-5783. Ricky Christian, Petitioner v. Jim Larkin, et al. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Har-
din v. Straub, 490 U. S. (1989).
—
No. 88-6316. Gary L. Blankenship, Petitioner v. Robert Parratt,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Hardin v. Straub, 490 U. S. — (1989).
No. 88-6434. Derek A. Farmer, Petitioner v. Richard P. Seiter,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Hardin v. Straub, 490 U. S. (1989). Justice
O'Connor, Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy would deny certiorari.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
No. . Alcolac, Inc., Petitioner v. Betty Elam, et al. The motion to
dispense with printing the appendix to the petition for a writ of certio-
rari is granted.

TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1989
679
No. William N. Paskulka, et ux., Petitioners v. Frank N. Koob,
et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to docket an appeal, out-of-time, is
denied.
No. D-762. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Steven Kotzker.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-773. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Lee Gagen. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-790. In the Matter of Disbarment of John P. Fitzgerald. It is
ordered that John P. Fitzgerald, of Jupiter, Florida, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 88-1784. Great Republic Insurance Company, et al., Petitioners
v. LaVerne Cheval, by and through her Conservator, Martin Miller.
The application for stay presented to Justice O'Connor and by her
referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that the judgment of
the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District, case
No. A040344, entered January 5, 1989, is stayed pending disposition of
the petition for writ of certiorari. In the event the petition for a writ of
certiorari is denied, this order terminates automatically. Should the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari be granted, this order is to remain in effect
pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court. This order is further
conditioned upon the certificates of deposit presently in the custody of
the California Superior Court remaining in effect.
No. 88-7146. Jonas H. Whitmore, individually and as next friend of
Ronald Gene Simmons v. Arkansas, et al. The motion of respondent
Simmons for expedited review is denied. The motion of respondent
Simmons for oral argument is denied. The motion of respondent
Simmons to be present at oral argument is denied. The motion of re-
spondent Simmons to require petitioner to post bond is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 88-1650. Francine Tafflin, et al., Petitioners, v. Jeffrey A.
Levitt, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted limited to Question 2 presented
by the petition.

OPINIONS
No. 87–1661. ASARCO Incorporated, et al., Petitioners v. Frank
Kadish, et ux., et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ari-
zona. Judgment affirmed. Justice Kennedy delivered the opinion of the
Court except as to Part II-B-I. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring
in part and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, and Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by the Chief Justice
concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Scalia
joins. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 87–201. Gerald E. Mansell, Appellant v. Gaye M. Mansell. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appellate District.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeal for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with
whom Justice Blackmun joins.
The Chief Justice says:
"The Court at this time wishes to note for the record that William C.
Bryson has been serving as Acting Solicitor General since January past.

TUESDAY, MAY 30, 1989
693
The Court recognizes the grave responsibility that has been placed
upon you, Mr. Bryson, to represent the government of the United
States before this Court. On behalf of my colleagues, I thank you for a
job well done and you have our sincere appreciation. At this time the
Court recognizes the Acting Solicitor General William C. Bryson, Jr."
Acting Solicitor General William C. Bryson presented the Honorable
Kenneth W. Starr, Solicitor General of the United States, to the Court.
The Chief Justice says:
"Mr. Solicitor General, the Court welcomes you to the performance of
the important office that you have assumed, to represent the govern-
ment of the United States before this Court. You follow in the footsteps
of other outstanding Circuit Judges who have held your new office, in-
cluding a member of this bench, Justice Marshall. Your commission will
be duly recorded by the Clerk."

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 5, 1989
697
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Mar-
shall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, and Justice
Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-1423. Theodore F. Kopfman, Apppellant v. Margie D. Kopf-
man. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appellate
District. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appellate District, for further con-
sideration in light of Mansell v. Mansell, 490 U. S. — (1989).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Tuan Anh Nguyen, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. The motion to
file a petition for writ of certiorari without an affidavit of indigency
executed by the petitioner is granted.
No. . Bradley J. Follett, Petitioner v. George Herman. The mo-
tion for leave to file a petition for writ of habeas corpus and other relief
is denied.
No. D-772. In the Matter of Disbarment of Rembert Thomas
Brown. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-775. In the Matter of David Hardin Graves. David Hardin
Graves, of Houston, Texas, having requested to resign as a member of
the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on March 20, 1989, is hereby
discharged.
No. 88-599. Washington, et al., Petitioners v. Walter Harper. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument
as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 88-1198. Federal Trade Commission, Petitioner v. Superior
Court Trial Lawyers Association; and
No. 88-1393. Superior Court Trial Lawyers Association, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Federal Trade Commission. The motion of the parties to dis-
pense with printing the joint appendix is granted.

698
MONDAY, JUNE 5, 1989
No. 88-7246. Roderick Herman Frey, Petitioner v. Pennsylvania.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented
to Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court is denied. Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Stevens
would grant the application.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
-
No. 87-1955. Gerald A. Lewis, etc., Appellant v. Continental Bank
Corporation, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

leum Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 88-1369. Maryland, Petitioner v. Jerome Edward Buie. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland
granted.
No. 88-6613. Richard Boyde, Petitioner v. California. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California granted.

OPINIONS
No. 87-963. Robert L. Hernandez, Petitioner v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit; and
No. 87-1616. Katherine Jean Graham, et al., Petitioners v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom
Justice Scalia joins. Justice Brennan and Justice Kennedy took no part
in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 87-1868. Mead Corporation, Petitioner v. B. E. Tilley, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 88-293. Community for Creative Non-Violence, et al., Petition-
ers v. James Earl Reid. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 87-1387. Wards Cove Packing Company, Inc., et al., Petition-
ers v. Frank Atonio, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Mar-
shall, and Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Black-
mun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 87-6405. Phillip D. Tompkins, Petitioner v. Texas. On writ
of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgment

708
MONDAY, JUNE 5, 1989
affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced
by the Chief Justice. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1989
713
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1382. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Mau-
reen A. Staples, et vir. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded.
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Hernandez v. Commissioner of Internal Reve-
nue, 490 U.S. (1989). Justice Brennan and Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
-
No. 87–1954. Consolidated City of Jacksonville, Duval County, Flor-
ida, etc., Petitioner v. Winston Nash. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Wards Cove Pack-
ing Company, Inc. v. Atonio, 490 U.S. (1989).
No. 88–102. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Mi-
chael F. Foley, et ux. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further
consideration in light of Hernandez v. Commissioner of Internal Reve-
nue, 490 U.S. (1989). Justice Brennan and Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 88-141. USX Corporation, fka United States Steel Corporation,
Petitioner v. Elbert G. Green and Robert Danley, etc. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals.
for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of Wards Cove
Packing Company, Inc. v. Atonio, 490 U.S. (1989).
-

714
MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1989
No. 88-1742. Paul Adams, et al., Petitioners v. Avco Corporation, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company v. Bruch, 489 U.S. (1989).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
No. —. Lawrence D. Caldwell, Petitioner v. Norman A. Carlson,
Director, Federal Bureau of Prisons. The motion to direct the Clerk to
file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
-
No. . In Re Michael W. Mason, et ux. The motion for leave to file
a petition for writ of mandamus and other relief is denied.
-
No. —. Darrell Prows, Petitioner v. Joseph F. Spaniol, Jr., et al.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari
without a notarized affidavit in support of the motion for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. . Darrell Prows, Petitioner v. United States, et al. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari without a
notarized affidavit in support of the motion for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied.
No. —. Gregory Thompson, Petitioner v. Tennessee. The motion.
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by the petitioner is granted.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motion of New York for judgment on the pleadings against Texas is
referred to the Special Master. The motion of Idaho for leave to file a
complaint in intervention is referred to the Special Master. The motion.
of Arizona for leave to file a complaint in intervention is referred to the
Special Master. The motion of Alabama, et al. for leave to file a com-
plaint in intervention is referred to the Special Master. The motion of
Connecticut for leave to intervene is referred to the Special Master.
The motion of New Mexico for leave to intervene is referred to the Spe-
cial Master. The motion of Tennessee for leave to intervene is referred
to the Special Master. The motion of Wisconsin for leave to intervene is
referred to the Special Master. The motion of Virginia for leave to in-
tervene is referred to the Special Master. The motion of the District of
Columbia for leave to intervene is referred to the Special Master.
No. D-791. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerril J. Krowen. It is
ordered that Jerril J. Krowen, of Boston, Massachusetts, be suspended

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1989
715
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 87–1979. Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Nancy J. Schwalb and William McGlone; and
No. 88-127. Norfolk & Western Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Robert T. Goode, Jr. The motion of respondents for divided argument
is denied.
No. 88-42. Olaf A. Hallstrom, et ux., Petitioners v. Tillamook
County. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 88-1000. New York, Petitioner v. Bernard Harris. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The mo-
tion of respondent to dismiss writ as improvidently granted is denied.
No. 88-1178. Thomas E. Keane, Petitioner v. United States. The
application to suspend the effect of the order denying certiorari pre-
sented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is denied.
Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.

the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.

titioner v. Doris Stamey. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United

nor took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

OPINIONS
No. 87-1428. Patricia A. Lorance, et al., Petitioners v. AT&T Tech-
nologies, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun
join. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 88-616. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Elmer Hudson. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom the Chief
Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 88-681. California State Board of Equalization, Petitioner v. Si-
erra Summit, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall
join.
No. 88-5014. Jose Gomez, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 88-5158. Diego Chavez-Tesina, Petitioner v. United States. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 88-774. Newman-Green, Inc., Petitioner v. Alejandro Alfonzo-
Larrain, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Kennedy with whom Justice Scalia joins.

MONDAY, JUNE 12, 1989
731
No. 88-305. South Carolina, Petitioner v. Demetrius Gathers. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring statement by Justice
White. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice Kennedy join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 88-333. Alabama, Petitioner v. James Lewis Smith. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 87-1614. John W. Martin, et al., Petitioners v. Robert K. Wilks,
et al.;
No. 87-1639. Personnel Board of Jefferson County, Alabama, et al.,
Petitioners v. Robert K. Wilks, et al.; and
No. 87-1668. Richard Arrington, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. Robert K.
Wilks, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the
Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 87-1165. California, et al., Petitioners v. United States, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per
curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Thursday, June 15, 1989 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 1989
735
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 88–396. Colonial American Life Insurance Company, Petitioner
v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 87-1855. Carl S. Dellmuth, Acting Secretary of Education of
Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Russell A. Muth, Jr., et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Black-
mun, and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 87–107. Brenda Patterson, Petitioner v. McLean Credit Union.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, vacated in part, and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by
Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in
part with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join and with
whom Justice Stevens joins as to Parts II-B, II-C, and III. Opinion by
Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in
part.
No. 87-746. Michael H. and Victoria D., Appellants v. Gerald D. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
Judgment affirmed. Justice Scalia announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which the Chief Justice joins in all but note 6
of which Justice O'Connor and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor concurring in part with whom Justice Kennedy joins. Opinion
by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun

736
THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 1989
join. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 88-1048. Robert J. Quinn, Jr. and Patricia J. Kampsen, etc., Ap-
pellants v. Wayne L. Millsap, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Missouri. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 87-1207. Ray Will, Petitioner v. Michigan Department of State
Police, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Michigan.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 87-1241. Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Union Gas Company. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Justice Brennan announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an
opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I and II, and an opinion with
respect to Part III, in which Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens join. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice White with whom the Chief Justice, Justice
O'Connor and Justice Kennedy join as to Part I. Opinion by Justice
Scalia concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom the Chief
Justice, Justice O'Connor and Justice Kennedy join as to Parts II, III,
and IV. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 87-6997. Eugene John Carella, Appellant v. California. Appeal
from the Appellate Department, Superior Court of California, Los An-
geles County. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Superior
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Opinion by
Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 19, 1989 at 10 o'clock.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 88-7461. Ronald Raymond Woomer, Petitioner v. Parker Evatt,
Commissioner, South Carolina Department of Corrections, et al. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death, presented to the

THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 1989
737
Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending the
disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of this
Court.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 88-7447. Leo Edwards, Petitioner v. Mississippi. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi is denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1989
739
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-1753. S. T., on behalf of her minor child, N. T., Appellant v.
Board of Education of the City of Millville, New Jersey, et al. Appeal
from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-5795. William Salazar and Beimar Vallejo, Petitioners v.
United States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certio-
rari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further
consideration in light of Gomez v. United States, 490 U. S. — (1989).
No. 88-6122. Pavit Nittayanupap, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Gomez v. United States, 490 U. S. (1989).
-
No. 88-6725. T. J. Hayes, Petitioner v. A. L. Lockhart, Director,
Arkansas Department of Correction. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit for further consideration in light of South Carolina v. Gathers,
490 U. S. (1989).

740
MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1989
No. 88-6729. Michael Daniels, Petitioner v. Indiana. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Indiana for further consideration in
light of South Carolina v. Gathers, 490 U. S. (1989).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
In Re David I. Dennis. The motion to direct the Clerk to
file a petition for a writ of habeas corpus is denied.
No. A-944. Ruth E. Prevenslik, etc., Applicant v. Elmer Rossko, et
al. The application for stay addressed to Justice Kennedy and referred
to the Court is denied.
No. D-784. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry G. Lillback. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-792. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brian D. Schaefer. It is
ordered that Brian D. Schaefer, of Longwood, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-793. In the Matter of Disbarment of Prince Cartwright, Jr.
It is ordered that Prince Cartwright, Jr., of Houston, Texas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-794. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ruben R. Montemayor.
It is ordered that Ruben R. Montemayor, of San Antonio, Texas, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 88-1353. United States, Petitioner v. Rene Martin Verdugo-
Urquidez. The motion of Criminal Justice Legal Foundation for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 88-1640. Michigan Citizens for an Independent Press, et al.,
Petitioners v. Dick Thornburgh, Attorney General of the United
States, et al. The motion of the parties to dispense with printing the
joint appendix is granted. Justice White took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion.

OPINIONS
No. 88-420. Jimmy Jones, Superintendent, Missouri Training Cen-
ter for Men at Moberly, Petitioner v. Larry P. Thomas. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom
Justice Stevens joins and with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall join as to all but the footnote.
No. 88-348. New Orleans Public Service, Inc., Petitioner v. Council
of City of New Orleans, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case

MONDAY, JUNE 19, 1989
753
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion
by the Chief Justice concurring in Parts I and II-B and concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment.
No. 88-449. John F. Healy, et al., Appellants v. The Beer Institute,
et al.; and
No. 88-513. Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of Connecticut, Inc., Ap-
pellant v. The Beer Institute, et al. Appeals from the United States

by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice
with whom Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 88-1. Consolidated Rail Corporation, Petitioner v. Railway

States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 88-64. Missouri, et al., Petitioners v. Kalima Jenkins, by her
friend, Kamau Agyei, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and
dissenting in part with whom Justice Scalia joins and with whom the
Chief Justice joins in part. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 20, 1989
757
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 88-7235. George C. Gilmore, Petitioner v. William Armontrout,
Warden. On motion to vacate stay. The motion of respondent to vacate
the order staying the execution of sentence of death entered by Justice
Blackmun on June 16, 1989 is granted. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting statement by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 88-7530. Leo Edwards, Jr., Petitioner v. Lee Roy Black, Com-
missioner, Mississippi Department of Corrections. The application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White and
by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit is de-
nied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1012. Randy Lynn McKinney, Applicant v. Idaho. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting state-
ment by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1025. Leonard Marvin Laws, by and through Marvin E.
Laws, as his next friend, Applicant v. Paul Delo, Superintendent, Po-
tosi Correctional Center. The application for stay of execution of sen-
tence of death presented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to
the Court is granted pending the timely filing and disposition by this
Court of a petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of
certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event
the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue
pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

758
TUESDAY, JUNE 20, 1989
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1027. Paul Delo, Superintendent, Potosi Correctional Center,
Applicant v. George C. Gilmore. The application of the Attorney Gen-
eral of Missouri for an order to vacate the stay of execution of sentence
of death entered by the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Missouri presented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred
to the Court is denied.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 21, 1989
759
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-1651. Massachusetts, Petitioner v. Douglas Oakes. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice
O'Connor announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opin-
ion with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice Kennedy
join. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment in part and
dissenting in part with whom Justice Blackmun joins and with whom
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join as to Part I.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and
Justice Stevens join.
No. 88-40. United States, Petitioner v. Frank S. Zolin, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court in part, vacated in
part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the judgment of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 87-329. The Florida Star, Appellant v. B.J.F. Appeal from the
District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the District Court of Appeal for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Marshall. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and concurring in
the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 87-1589. Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al.; and
No. 87-1888. Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al. On writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The judg-
ment in No. 87-1888 is reversed and the judgment in No. 87-1589 is va-
cated and the cases are remanded to the Court of Appeals for further

760
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 21, 1989
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice White. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Jus-
tice Blackmun join.
No. 88-429. Public Citizen, Appellant v. United States Department
of Justice, et al.; and
No. 88-494. Washington Legal Foundation, Appellant v. United
States Department of Justice, et al. Appeals from the United States.
District Court for the District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the
judgment with whom the Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join. Jus-
tice Scalia took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 88-155. Texas, Petitioner v. Gregory Lee Johnson. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Justice
Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
White and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

Department of Income Maintenance, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Justice White announced the judgment of the Court and deliv-
ered an opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice O'Connor and Justice
Kennedy join. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun, and Justice
Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Blackmun joins.

Federal Communications Commission, et al.; and
No. 88-525. Federal Communications Commission, et al., Appellants
v. Sable Communications of California, Inc. Appeals from the United
States District Court for the Central District of California. Judgments
affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice
Scalia. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join.

Nordberg, Creditor Trustee for the Estate of Chase & Sanborn Cor-

764
FRIDAY, JUNE 23, 1989
peals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice
Scalia concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with
whom Justice O'Connor joins.
No. 88-411. Edward W. Murray, Director, Virginia Department of
Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. Joseph M. Giarratano, Johnny Wat-

United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. The Chief Justice an-
nounced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which
Justice White, Justice O'Connor, and Justice Scalia join. Concurring
opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in
the judgment with whom Justice O'Connor joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Jus-
tice Blackmun join.

MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1989
765
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1293. Jeetendra Bhandari, Petitioner v. First National Bank
of Commerce. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Patterson v. McLean Credit Union, 491 U.S.
(1989).
No. 87-1631. Burlington Northern Railroad Company, Petitioner v.
Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion
of Equal Employment Advisory Council for leave to file a brief as ami-
cus curiae is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Skinner v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, 489 U.S. -
(1989).
No. 87-2049. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al., Petition-
ers v. Chicago & North Western Transportation Company, et al. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company v. Railway Labor Execu-
tives' Association, 491 U.S. — (1989).
-
·
No. 88-517. City of Galveston, Texas, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Rail-
way Labor Executives' Association, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the

766
MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1989
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Pittsburgh & Lake
Erie Railroad Company v. Railway Labor Executives' Association,
491 U.S. (1989).
No. 88-955. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Merit
Life Insurance Company. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of Colonial American Life Insur-
ance Company v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, 491 U.S.
(1989).
No. 88-1063. Tennessee, Petitioner v. James Howard Turner. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Alabama v. Smith, 490 U.S. — (1989).
No. 88-1282. Brown-Forman Corporation, Petitioner v. Tennessee
Alcoholic Beverage Commission, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Healy v. The Beer Institute,
Inc., 491 U.S. — (1989).
-
No. 88-1486. Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority,
et al., Petitioners v. Transport Workers' Union of Philadelphia, Local
234, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Consolidated Rail Corporation v. Railway Labor Ex-
ecutives' Association, 491 U.S. (1989).
.
No. 88-1493. Thomas Sobol, Commissioner, New York State Depart-
ment of Education, Petitioner v. Clifford Burr, etc. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of Dellmuth v.
Muth, 491 U.S. (1989).

No. 88-1653. United Transportation Union, Petitioner v. Southeast-
ern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, et al. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Cir-
cuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is va-

for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of Skinner v.
Railway Labor Executives' Association, 489 U.S. (1989).

al., Petitioners v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al.; and
No. 88-1874. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al., Petition-

The petitions for writs of certiorari are granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the cases are remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Pitts-
burgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company v. Railway Labor Executives'
Association, 491 U.S. (1989).

et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Hardin v. Straub, 490 U.S. (1989).

No. 88-1449.
MacNamara; and
Korean Air Lines, Petitioner V. Thomas V.
No. 88-1551. Thomas V. MacNamara, Petitioner v. Korean Air
Lines. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
No. 88-7139. Kriss L. Stutzman, Petitioner v. Board of Education of
the City of Chicago, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until July 17, 1989,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
APPEAL
JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 88-5986. Clyde Osborne, Appellant v. Ohio. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Ohio. The motion of appellant for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted
limited to Questions I.(b), I.(d) and II. presented by the statement as to
jurisdiction. With respect to the additional questions presented, the ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for a writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 88-1105. Curtis Guidry, Petitioner v. Sheet Metal Workers Na-
tional Pension Fund, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
