OPINIONS
No. 87-5765. Kevin N. Stanford, Petitioner v. Kentucky. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky; and

MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1989
781
No. 87-6026. Heath A. Wilkins, Petitioner v. Missouri. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri. Judgments affirmed. Jus-
tice Scalia announced the judgment of the Court and delivered the opin-
ion of Court with respect to Parts I, II, III, and IV-A, and an opinion
with respect to Parts IV-B and V in which the Chief Justice, Justice
White and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens join.
No. 87-6177. Johnny Paul Penry, Petitioner v. James A. Lynaugh,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed in part, reversed in part, and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Justice O'Connor announced the judgment of the Court and de-
livered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II-A, II–B, III,
IV-A and IV-B, and an opinion with respect to Part IV-C. Opinion by
Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom
Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part
and dissenting in part with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Opinion by
Justice Scalia concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom the
Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 88-556. Browning-Ferris Industries of Vermont, Inc., et al., Pe-
titioners v. Kelco Disposal, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Ste-
vens joins.
No. 87-1252. H. J. Inc., et al., etc., Petitioners v. Northwestern Bell
Telephone Company, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by
Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment with whom the Chief Justice,
Justice O'Connor and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 88-309. Wyoming, Petitioner v. United States, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wyoming. Judgment affirmed by an
equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Jus-
tice. Justice O'Connor took no part in the decision of this case.

782
MONDAY, JUNE 26, 1989
No. 88-317. Jack R. Duckworth, Petitioner v. Gary James Eagan. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice O'Connor
with whom Justice Scalia joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall
with whom Justice Brennan joins, and with whom Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens join as to Part I.
☑
Adjourned until Thursday, June 29, 1989 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 29, 1989
783
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-2013. Board of Trustees of the State University of New York,
et al., Petitioners v. Todd Fox, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall join.
No. 87-1622. Philip Brendale, Petitioner v. Confederated Tribes and
Bands of Yakima Indian Nation, et al.;
No. 87-1697. Stanley Wilkinson, Petitioner v. Confederated Tribes
and Bands of the Yakima Indian Nation, et al.; and
No. 87-1711. County of Yakima, et al., Petitioners v. Confederated
Tribes and Bands of the Yakima Indian Nation, et al. On writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
judgment in No. 87-1622 is affirmed. The judgment in Nos. 87-1697
and 87-1711 is reversed. Justice Stevens delivered an opinion announc-
ing the judgment of the Court in No. 87-1622 and concurring in the
judgment in Nos. 87-1697 and 87-1711 with whom Justice O'Connor
joins. Justice White delivered an opinion announcing the judgment of
the Court in Nos. 87-1697 and 87-1711 and dissenting in No. 87–1622
with whom the Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy join.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment in No. 87-
1622 and dissenting in Nos. 87-1697 and 87-1711 with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
The Chief Justice said:
"On Monday, July 3, 1989, the Court will announce all the remaining
opinions ready during the Term of the Court."
☑
Adjourned until Monday, July 3, 1989 at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JULY 3, 1989
785
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and Justice
Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS
No. 87-2050. County of Allegheny, et al., Petitioners v. American
Civil Liberties Union Greater Pittsburgh Chapter, et al.;
No. 88-90. Chabad, Petitioner v. American Civil Liberties Union, et
al.; and
No. 88-96. City of Pittsburgh, Petitioner v. American Civil Liberties
Union Pittsburgh Chapter, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed
in part, reversed in part and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Justice Blackmun announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion of the Court with respect to Parts III-A, IV, and V, an
opinion with respect to Parts I and II, with whom Justice O'Connor and
Justice Stevens join, an opinion with respect to Part III-B, with whom
Justice Stevens joins, and an opinion with respect to Part VI. Opinion
by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and concurring in the judgment
with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Stevens join as to Part II.
Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part
with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by
Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom
Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Opinion by Justice Kennedy
concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part with whom
the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice Scalia join.
No. 88-605. William L. Webster, Attorney General of Missouri,
et al., Appellants v. Reproductive Health Services, et al. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. The Chief Justice
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the
Court with respect to Parts I, II-A, II-B, and II-C, and an opinion

786
MONDAY, JULY 3, 1989
with respect to Parts II-D and III with whom Justice White and
Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in
part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Blackmun
concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall join. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part
and dissenting in part.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 88-6801. David Lee Powell, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is reversed and case is
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 88-1819. Robert L. McCordic, Appellant v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1051. Russell Hobson, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of H. J. Inc. v. Northwestern Bell Telephone Company, 492 U. S.
(1989).
No. 87-1358. Marshall-Silver Construction Company, Inc., and Sil-
ver Construction, Inc., Petitioners v. M. Mark Mendel, et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of H. J.
Inc. v. Northwestern Bell Telephone Company, 492 U. S. — (1989).
The Chief Justice, Justice White, Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor
would deny certiorari.

No. 88-192. McKesson Corporation, Petitioner v. Division of Alco-
holic Beverages and Tobacco, Department of Business Regulation of
Florida, et al.; and
No. 88-325. American Trucking Associations, Inc., et al., Petitioners
v. Maurice Smith, Director, Arkansas Highway and Transportation
Department, et al. These cases are restored to the Calendar for
reargument. In No. 88-192, the parties are directed to brief and argue
the following questions in addition to the issues already briefed:
1. "When a taxpayer pays under protest a state tax found to violate
clearly established law under the Commerce Clause must the State pro-
vide some form of retrospective relief, such as a tax refund or an offset-
ting tax on past beneficiaries of the tax preference, or may the State
elect to provide only prospective relief?"
2. "May a State, consistently with the Due Process Clause of the
14th Amendment, remedy the effects of a tax found to discriminate
against an interstate business in violation of the Dormant Commerce

790
MONDAY, JULY 3, 1989
Clause by retroactively raising the taxes of those who benefited from
the discrimination?"
Each case is allotted 45 minutes for reargument.
No. 88-6896. Charles F. Schaefer, Petitioner v. Transportation
Media, Inc., etc. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order
denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 88-1805. Eastern Nebraska Community Office of Retardation,
et al., Petitioners v. Patricia Ann Glover, et al. The Solicitor General is
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 88-6995. Charles Edward Moore, Petitioner v. California. The
respondent is requested to file a response to the petition for rehearing
within thirty days.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until the first Monday in Oc-
tober, 1989, at which time the October 1988 Term will adjourn.
The Chief Justice said:
“I am authorized to announce that all of the cases and other matters
before the Court which were ready for disposition, have been acted
upon by the Court. Accordingly, it is ordered that those cases remain-
ing on the docket, but not ready for consideration are continued to the
Session of the Court beginning October 2, 1989.
The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in Octo-
ber, 1989, at which time the October 1988 Term of the Court will be

804
MONDAY, JULY 3, 1989
adjourned and the October 1989 Term of the Court will begin as pro-
vided by statute on the first Monday in October.
Because of certain fiscal constraints, this has been a particularly try-
ing Term for the entire Supreme Court staff-the housekeeping staff
and security forces, those who process the thousands of documents sub-
mitted for consideration, those who assist in our research and respond
to our myriad queries, those who assemble and publish our final prod-
uct. I speak for all of the members of the Court in thanking all of the
Supreme Court staff for his and her continued dedicated work during
the Term."

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JULY 12, 1989
805
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 88-7562. Eric Kimble, Petitioner v. Dan Vasquez, Warden. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is granted pending the
disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 89-5121. James William Hamblen, Petitioner v. Richard L.
Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition
by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition
for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In
the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall
continue pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1989
833
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 89-5621. Richard E. Grant, Petitioner v. Dan Vasquez, Warden.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is granted pending
the disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari.
Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay termi-
nates automatically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is
granted, this stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of
this Court.
